A company’s directors must secure that the financial year of each of its subsidiary undertakings coincides with the company’s financial year unless, in the directors’ opinion, there are good reasons against those financial years coinciding with each other.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: Undertaking
def.leadIn: undertaking (企業) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a body corporate;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a partnership; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an unincorporated association carrying on a trade or business, whether for profit or not.

section.name: s368
section.heading: Accounting reference period

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (1A), for an existing company formed and registered before the commencement date# of Division 1 of Part 3, the first accounting reference period begins on the date immediately following its primary accounting reference date and ends on the first anniversary of its primary accounting reference date. (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 40)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: For an existing company that was a dormant company at the beginning of the commencement date# of Division 1 of Part 3 but has ceased to be a dormant company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subsection (1) does not apply; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the first accounting reference period begins on the date the company ceased to be a dormant company and ends on its primary accounting reference date. (Added 35 of 2018 s. 40)

subsection.leadIn: For—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a company formed and registered under this Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a company formed and registered under a provision of the predecessor Ordinance having a continuing effect under Schedule 11 or by virtue of section 23 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1),

subsection.continued: the first accounting reference period begins on the date of its incorporation and ends on its primary accounting reference date.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: For a re-domiciled company, the first accounting reference period begins on its re-domiciliation date and ends on its primary accounting reference date. (Added 14 of 2025 s. 30)

Every subsequent accounting reference period of a company is the period of 12 months beginning immediately after the end of the previous accounting reference period and ending on its accounting reference date, unless the accounting reference period is shortened or extended, as stated in a directors’ resolution under section 371(3).

section.name: s369
section.heading: Primary accounting reference date

subsection.leadIn: For an existing company formed and registered before the commencement date# of Division 1 of Part 3, the primary accounting reference date is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the date up to which the company’s accounts are made if, on or after the commencement date# of this section, the company’s accounts—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: have been laid before the company in general meeting under section 122 of the predecessor Ordinance having a continuing effect under Schedule 11; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: have been provided to the members under section 111(6) of the predecessor Ordinance having a continuing effect under Schedule 11; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if, on or after the commencement date# of this section, such company’s accounts have not been laid or provided as mentioned in paragraph (a)(i) or (ii)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the case where such accounts have been prepared on or before the date by which the company is required by section 111(1) of the predecessor Ordinance having a continuing effect under Schedule 11 to hold a general meeting, the date up to which those accounts are made;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case where subparagraph (i) does not apply, but accounts made up to a date falling more than one day before the commencement date# of this section have been prepared on or before the date by which the company is required by that section 111(1) to hold a general meeting, the first anniversary of the date up to which those accounts are made; (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 41)

in the case where subparagraphs (i) and (ii) do not apply and the company is required by that section 111(1) to hold a general meeting, the date by which the meeting is required to be held; or (Replaced 35 of 2018 s. 41)

subparagraph.leadIn: in the case where subparagraphs (i) and (ii) do not apply, and the company was a dormant company at the beginning of the commencement date# of Division 1 of Part 3 but has ceased to be a dormant company—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: a date specified by the directors, which must fall within 18 months after the date the company ceased to be a dormant company; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: if no date is specified before the last day of the month in which the anniversary of the company’s incorporation first occurs after the company ceased to be a dormant company, the last day of the month. (Added 35 of 2018 s. 41)

subsection.content: Subsection (1)(a) and (b)(i) does not apply if those accounts are made up to a date falling more than one day before the commencement date# of this section.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1)(a)(i) does not apply unless the general meeting is held—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of the company’s first general meeting, within 18 months of the company’s incorporation; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, within 15 months, and in the year, after the company’s last annual general meeting.

subsection.content: Subsection (1)(b)(ii) does not apply if those accounts are made up to a date falling more than one day before the beginning of the period of 12 months before the commencement date# of this section.

subsection.leadIn: For any of the companies specified in subsection (6A), the primary accounting reference date is— (Amended 14 of 2025 s. 31)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a date specified by the directors before the relevant date for the purposes of this paragraph; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the absence of such a specified date, the relevant date.

subsection.leadIn: A date specified for the purposes of subsection (5)(a)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a company that is not a re-domiciled company—must fall within 18 months after the date of the company’s incorporation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a re-domiciled company—must fall within 18 months after the re-domiciliation date. (Replaced 14 of 2025 s. 31)

subsection.name: 6A
subsection.leadIn: The following companies are specified for the purposes of subsection (5)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a company formed and registered under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a company formed and registered under a provision of the predecessor Ordinance having a continuing effect under Schedule 11 or by virtue of section 23 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a re-domiciled company. (Added 14 of 2025 s. 31)

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: RelevantDate
def.leadIn: relevant date (有關日期)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to a company that is not a re-domiciled company—means the last day of the month in which the relevant anniversary of the company’s incorporation falls; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to a re-domiciled company—means the last day of the month in which the anniversary of the re-domiciliation date of the company falls. (Replaced 14 of 2025 s. 31)

section.name: s370
section.heading: Accounting reference date
section.content: Subject to section 371, a company’s accounting reference date is the anniversary of its primary accounting reference date.

section.name: s371
section.heading: Alteration of accounting reference date

subsection.leadIn: The directors of a company may specify a new accounting reference date in relation to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the company’s current accounting reference period and every subsequent accounting reference period; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the company’s previous accounting reference period and every subsequent accounting reference period.

subsection.content: If the directors of a public company or a company limited by guarantee specify a new accounting reference date under subsection (1), the company must, within 15 days after the date of the directors’ resolution specifying the new accounting reference date, deliver a notice, in the specified form, of that new date to the Registrar for registration.

subsection.leadIn: A directors’ resolution by which a new accounting reference date is specified, and a notice of that new date delivered to the Registrar, must state—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether the current or previous accounting reference period concerned is to be shortened, so as to end on the first occasion on which the new accounting reference date falls or fell after the beginning of that period; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether the current or previous accounting reference period concerned is to be extended, so as to end on the second occasion on which the new accounting reference date falls or fell after the beginning of that period.

subsection.leadIn: The directors of a company must not specify a new accounting reference date in relation to the previous accounting reference period if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the period for laying before the company in general meeting under section 429 a copy of the reporting documents for the financial year determined by reference to that accounting reference period has expired; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the period for sending a copy of the reporting documents for the financial year to the members under section 430(3) has expired.

subsection.content: The directors of a company must not specify a new accounting reference date in relation to an accounting reference period so as to extend the period to longer than 18 months.

subsection.leadIn: The directors of a company must not specify a new accounting reference date in relation to the current or previous accounting reference period so as to extend that period if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: those directors have specified a new accounting reference date in relation to an earlier accounting reference period so as to extend that earlier period; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the earlier accounting reference period ended within 5 years before the new accounting reference date is specified.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (6) does not apply if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the new accounting reference date to be specified by the directors coincides with the accounting reference date of a holding company of the company; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the specification is approved by a members’ resolution.

subsection.content: If a company contravenes subsection (2), the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 3 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $300 for each day during which the offence continues.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: previous accounting reference period (對上的會計參照期), in relation to a company, means the accounting reference period of the company immediately preceding the company’s current accounting reference period.

division.name: D4
division.heading: Preparation of Financial Statements and Directors’ Reports

section.name: s372
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: in electronic form (電子形式) means in the form of an electronic record;
in hard copy form (印本形式) means in a paper form or similar form capable of being read.

section.name: s373
section.heading: Company must keep accounting records

subsection.content: A company must keep accounting records that comply with subsections (2) and (3).

subsection.leadIn: The accounting records must be sufficient—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to show and explain the company’s transactions;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to disclose with reasonable accuracy, at any time, the company’s financial position and financial performance; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to enable the directors to ensure that the financial statements comply with this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: In particular, the accounting records must contain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: daily entries of all sums of money received and expended by the company, and the matters in respect of which the receipt and expenditure takes place; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a record of the company’s assets and liabilities.

subsection.content: If subsection (1) does not apply in relation to a subsidiary undertaking of a company, the company must take all reasonable steps to secure that the subsidiary undertaking keeps accounting records that are sufficient to enable the company’s directors to ensure that any financial statements required to be prepared under Subdivision 3 of Division 4 comply with this Ordinance.
A director of a company who fails to take all reasonable steps to secure compliance with subsection (1) or (4) commits an offence and is liable to a fine of $300,000.

A director of a company who wilfully fails to take all reasonable steps to secure compliance with subsection (1) or (4) commits an offence and is liable to a fine of $300,000 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

subsection.leadIn: If a person is charged with an offence under subsection (5), it is a defence to establish that the person had reasonable grounds to believe, and did believe, that a competent and reliable person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: was charged with the duty of ensuring that subsection (1) or (4) (as the case may be) was complied with; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: was in a position to discharge that duty.

section.name: s374
section.heading: Where accounting records to be kept

subsection.leadIn: A company’s accounting records—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be kept at its registered office or any other place that the directors think fit; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be open to inspection by the directors at all times without charge.

subsection.leadIn: If a company’s accounting records are kept at a place outside Hong Kong, the accounts and returns with respect to the business dealt with in those records—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be sent to, and kept at, a place in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be open to inspection by the directors at all times without charge.

subsection.leadIn: Those accounts and returns—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must disclose with reasonable accuracy the financial position of the business in question at intervals of not more than 6 months; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be sufficient to enable the directors to ensure that any financial statements required to be prepared under Subdivision 3 of Division 4 comply with this Ordinance.

subsection.content: A director of a company who fails to take all reasonable steps to secure compliance with subsection (1), (2) or (3) commits an offence and is liable to a fine of $300,000.

A director of a company who wilfully fails to take all reasonable steps to secure compliance with subsection (1), (2) or (3) commits an offence and is liable to a fine of $300,000 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

subsection.leadIn: If a person is charged with an offence under subsection (4), it is a defence to establish that the person had reasonable grounds to believe, and did believe, that a competent and reliable person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: was charged with the duty of ensuring that subsection (1), (2) or (3) (as the case may be) was complied with; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: was in a position to discharge that duty.

section.name: s375
section.heading: Director may obtain copies of accounting records during inspection

subsection.content: A company must allow a director of the company to make a copy of its accounting records in the course of inspection.
A company must provide a director of the company with a copy of its accounting records without charge if so requested by the director.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the director requests a copy of the company’s accounting records in hard copy form, the company must provide the copy in hard copy form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the director requests a copy of the company’s accounting records in electronic form, the company must provide the copy in any electronic form that the company thinks fit.

subsection.content: Subsections (2) and (3) do not require a company to provide a director of the company with a copy of its accounting records in electronic form if it keeps its accounting records by recording the information in hard copy form only.

subsection.leadIn: If any accounting records are kept by a company by recording the information in electronic form, a requirement under this Subdivision for the accounting records to be open to inspection is to be regarded as a requirement—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a reproduction of the recording in hard copy form to be open to inspection; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the recording to be open to inspection by electronic means at the request of a person entitled to inspect the accounting records.

subsection.content: A director of a company who fails to take all reasonable steps to secure compliance with subsection (1) or (2) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 5 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $1,000 for each day during which the offence continues.

subsection.leadIn: If a person is charged with an offence under subsection (6), it is a defence to establish that the person had reasonable grounds to believe, and did believe, that a competent and reliable person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: was charged with the duty of ensuring that subsection (1) or (2) (as the case may be) was complied with; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: was in a position to discharge that duty.

section.name: s376
section.heading: Form of accounting records

subsection.content: The information contained in a company’s accounting records must be adequately recorded such that they are available for future reference.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (1), a company’s accounting records may be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: kept in hard copy form or electronic form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: arranged in the manner that the directors think fit.

subsection.content: If a company’s accounting records are kept in electronic form, the company must ensure that those records are capable of being reproduced in hard copy form.

subsection.leadIn: If any accounting records are kept by a company otherwise than by making entries in a bound book, the company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must take adequate precautions to guard against falsification; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must take adequate steps to facilitate the discovery of a falsification.

subsection.content: If subsection (1) is contravened, the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 3 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $300 for each day during which the offence continues.
If subsection (3) or (4) is contravened, the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 3.

section.name: s377
section.heading: How long accounting records to be preserved

subsection.content: This section applies to any accounting records, or any accounts and returns, that are required by section 373(1) or 374(2) to be kept.

The company must preserve the records, or the accounts and returns, for 7 years after the end of the financial year to which the last entry made or matter recorded in the records, or the accounts and returns, relates.
A director of a company who fails to take all reasonable steps to secure compliance with subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable to a fine of $300,000.

A director of a company who wilfully fails to take all reasonable steps to secure compliance with subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable to a fine of $300,000 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

subsection.leadIn: If a person is charged with an offence under subsection (3), it is a defence to establish that the person had reasonable grounds to believe, and did believe, that a competent and reliable person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: was charged with the duty of ensuring that subsection (2) was complied with; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: was in a position to discharge that duty.

section.name: s378
section.heading: Court may order accounting records to be inspected on director’s behalf

subsection.content: On application by a director of a company, the Court may by order authorize a person to inspect the company’s accounting records on the director’s behalf.
Unless the Court otherwise directs, a person so authorized may make copies of the accounting records.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may make any or all of the following orders—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order limiting the use that a person so authorized may make of the information obtained during the inspection;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order limiting the right of a person so authorized to make copies in accordance with subsection (2);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any other order that it thinks fit.

section.name: s379
section.heading: Directors must prepare financial statements

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), a company’s directors must prepare for each financial year statements that comply with sections 380 and 383.

Subject to subsection (3A), if the company is a holding company at the end of the financial year, the directors must instead prepare for the financial year consolidated statements that comply with sections 380, 381 and 383.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (3A) applies— (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 42)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the company is a wholly owned subsidiary of another body corporate at the end of the financial year;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the company is a partially owned subsidiary of another body corporate at the end of the financial year;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: at least 6 months before the end of the financial year, the directors notify the members in writing of the directors’ intention not to prepare consolidated statements for the financial year, and the notification does not relate to any other financial year; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: as at a date falling 3 months before the end of the financial year, no member has responded to the notification by giving the directors a written request for the preparation of consolidated statements for the financial year; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: if—

subparagraph.content: the company is a partially owned subsidiary of another body corporate at the end of the financial year; and

all members agree in writing before the end of the financial year that consolidated statements will not be prepared for the financial year, and the agreement does not relate to any other financial year. (Added 35 of 2018 s. 42)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.leadIn: If this subsection applies because of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: subsection (3)(a)—the directors must prepare for the financial year—

subparagraph.content: statements that comply with sections 380 and 383; or
consolidated statements that comply with sections 380, 381 and 383; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subsection (3)(b) or (c)—the directors must prepare for the financial year statements that comply with sections 380 and 383. (Added 35 of 2018 s. 42)

subsection.content: If, as respects any financial statements a copy of which is laid before a company in general meeting under section 429, or sent to a member under section 430 or otherwise circulated, published or issued by the company, a director of the company fails to take all reasonable steps to secure compliance with subsection (1), (2) or (3A), the director commits an offence and is liable to a fine of $300,000.

If, as respects any financial statements a copy of which is laid before a company in general meeting under section 429, or sent to a member under section 430 or otherwise circulated, published or issued by the company, a director of the company wilfully fails to take all reasonable steps to secure compliance with subsection (1), (2) or (3A), the director commits an offence and is liable to a fine of $300,000 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

subsection.leadIn: If a person is charged with an offence under subsection (4), it is a defence to establish that the person had reasonable grounds to believe, and did believe, that a competent and reliable person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: was charged with the duty of ensuring that subsection (1), (2) or (3A) (as the case may be) was complied with; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: was in a position to discharge that duty.

section.name: s380
section.heading: General requirements for financial statements

subsection.leadIn: The annual financial statements for a financial year—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must give a true and fair view of the financial position of the company as at the end of the financial year; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must give a true and fair view of the financial performance of the company for the financial year.

subsection.leadIn: The annual consolidated financial statements for a financial year—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must give a true and fair view of the financial position of the company, and all the subsidiary undertakings, as a whole as at the end of the financial year; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must give a true and fair view of the financial performance of the company, and all the subsidiary undertakings, as a whole for the financial year.

subsection.leadIn: The financial statements for a financial year must comply with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the company falls within the reporting exemption for the financial year, Part 1 of Schedule 4; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the company does not fall within the reporting exemption for the financial year, Parts 1 and 2 of Schedule 4.

subsection.leadIn: The financial statements for a financial year must also comply with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any other requirements of this Ordinance in relation to the financial statements; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the accounting standards applicable to the financial statements.

subsection.content: If, in relation to any financial statements, compliance with subsections (3) and (4) would be insufficient to give a true and fair view under subsection (1) or (2), the financial statements must contain all additional information necessary for that purpose.

subsection.leadIn: If, in relation to any financial statements, compliance with subsection (3) or (4) would be inconsistent with a requirement to give a true and fair view under subsection (1) or (2), the financial statements—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must depart from subsection (3) or (4) (as the case may be) to the extent necessary for it to give a true and fair view; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must contain the reasons for, and the particulars and effect of, the departure.

subsection.content: Subsections (1), (2), (5) and (6) do not apply if the company falls within the reporting exemption for the financial year.
This section has effect subject to section 382.

section.name: s381
section.heading: Subsidiary undertakings to be included in annual consolidated financial statements

subsection.content: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), the annual consolidated financial statements for a financial year must include all the subsidiary undertakings of the company.

Where the company falls within the reporting exemption for the financial year, one or more subsidiary undertakings may be excluded from the annual consolidated financial statements in compliance with the accounting standards applicable to the statements.

subsection.leadIn: Where the company does not fall within the reporting exemption for the financial year—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: one subsidiary undertaking may be excluded from the annual consolidated financial statements if the inclusion of the subsidiary undertaking is not material for the purpose of giving a true and fair view of the financial position, and of the financial performance, mentioned in section 380(2)(a) and (b); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: more than one subsidiary undertaking may be excluded from the annual consolidated financial statements if the inclusion of those subsidiary undertakings taken together is not material for the purpose of giving a true and fair view of the financial position, and of the financial performance, mentioned in section 380(2)(a) and (b).

subsection.content: This section has effect subject to section 382.

section.name: s382
section.heading: Provisions supplementary to sections 380 and 381

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if at any time during a financial year of a private company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the company registers any transfer of shares in the company in contravention of the restrictions imposed by the company’s articles;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the membership of the company exceeds the number specified in section 11(1)(a)(ii); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the company makes an invitation to the public to subscribe for any shares or debentures of the company.

subsection.content: The financial statements of the company for the financial year must comply with sections 380 and 381 as if the company were a public company.
The Court may, on the application of the company or a person interested in the matter, order that subsections (1) and (2) do not apply.
The Court may make the order on any terms and conditions that the Court thinks just and expedient.

subsection.leadIn: The Court must not make the order unless the Court is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the occurrence of the event mentioned in subsection (1)(a), (b) or (c) was accidental;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it was due to inadvertence or to some other sufficient cause that the event occurred; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: it is just and equitable to grant the relief on other grounds.

section.name: s383
section.heading: Notes to financial statements to contain information on directors’ emoluments etc.

subsection.leadIn: The financial statements for a financial year must contain, in the notes to the statements, the information prescribed by the Regulation for the purposes of this subsection about the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the directors’ emoluments;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the directors’ retirement benefits;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: payments made or benefit provided in respect of the termination of the service of directors, whether in the capacity of directors or in any other capacity while directors;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: loans, quasi-loans and other dealings in favour of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: directors of the company and of a holding company of the company;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: bodies corporate controlled by such directors; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: entities connected with such directors;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: material interests of directors in transactions, arrangements or contracts entered into by the company; (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 44)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: consideration provided to or receivable by third parties for making available the services of a person as director or in any other capacity while director.

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a reference to a director—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the case of subsection (1)(b), includes a former director;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of subsection (1)(c) includes a former director and shadow director; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: in the case of subsection (1)(d) and (e), includes a shadow director;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a reference to a body corporate controlled by a director has the meaning given by section 492; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a reference to an entity connected with a director has the meaning given by section 486.

subsection.content: Despite subsection (1)(d), the financial statements for a financial year are not required to contain the information prescribed by the Regulation for the purposes of that subsection if the company complies with the requirements prescribed by the Regulation for the purposes of this subsection.
The notes to any financial statements must also comply with other requirements prescribed by the Regulation.

subsection.leadIn: A person who is, or has been during the preceding 5 years, a director or shadow director of a company must give notice to the company of any matter that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is prescribed by the Regulation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: relates to the person; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is necessary for the purposes of subsection (1).

subsection.content: A person who contravenes subsection (5) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 5.

section.name: s384
section.heading: Register of particulars not required to be contained in notes to financial statements

subsection.content: A company must enter into a register the particulars that would, but for section 383(3), be required by section 383(1)(d) to be contained in the notes to the financial statements for a financial year.
A company must keep the particulars in the register for at least 10 years after the date on which the particulars are entered.
If a company contravenes subsection (1) or (2), the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 4.

section.name: s385
section.heading: Place where register mentioned in section 384 must be kept

subsection.leadIn: A company must keep the register mentioned in section 384 at—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the company’s registered office; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a place prescribed by regulations made under section 657.

subsection.content: A company must notify the Registrar of the place at which the register mentioned in section 384 is kept. The notice must be in the specified form and be delivered to the Registrar for registration within 15 days after the register is first kept at that place.

A company must notify the Registrar of any change (other than a change of the address of the company’s registered office) in the place at which the register mentioned in section 384 is kept. The notice must be in the specified form and be delivered to the Registrar for registration within 15 days after the change.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2) does not require a company to notify the Registrar of the place at which the register mentioned in section 384 is kept—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if, in the case of a register that came into existence on or after the commencement date# of this section, it has at all times been kept at the company’s registered office; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: immediately before that commencement date#, the company kept a register for the purposes of section 161BB of the predecessor Ordinance; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: on and after that commencement date#, that register is kept as a register for the purposes of section 384 at the place at which that register was kept immediately before that commencement date#. (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 45)

subsection.content: If a company contravenes subsection (1), (2) or (3), the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $700 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s386
section.heading: Right to inspect and request copy

subsection.content: A member of a company is entitled, on request made in the prescribed manner and without charge, to inspect the register kept by the company under section 384 in accordance with regulations made under section 657.

A member of a company is entitled, on request and on payment of a prescribed fee, to be provided with a copy of the register kept by the company under section 384, or any part of it, in accordance with regulations made under section 657.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: prescribed (訂明) means prescribed by regulations made under section 657.

section.name: s387
section.heading: Statement of financial position to be approved and signed

subsection.leadIn: A statement of financial position that forms part of any financial statements—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be approved by the directors; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: must be signed—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: by 2 directors on the directors’ behalf; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of a company having only one director, by the director.

subsection.content: Every copy of a statement of financial position that forms part of any financial statements laid before a company in general meeting under section 429, or sent to a member under section 430 or otherwise circulated, published or issued by the company, must state the name of the person who signed the statement on the directors’ behalf.

If, as respects any financial statements a copy of which is circulated, published or issued by the company, subsection (1) is contravened, the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 4.
If subsection (2) is contravened, the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 4.

section.name: s388
section.heading: Directors must prepare directors’ report

subsection.leadIn: A company’s directors must prepare for each financial year a report that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: complies with sections 390 and 543(2) and Schedule 5;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: contains the information prescribed by the Regulation; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: complies with other requirements prescribed by the Regulation.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (1), if the company is a holding company in a financial year, and the directors prepare annual consolidated financial statements for the financial year, the directors must instead prepare for the financial year a consolidated report that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: complies with sections 390 and 543(2) and Schedule 5;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: contains the information prescribed by the Regulation; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: complies with other requirements prescribed by the Regulation.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) or (2) does not require the directors’ report for a financial year to comply with Schedule 5 if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the company falls within the reporting exemption for the financial year;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the company is a wholly owned subsidiary of another body corporate at the end of the financial year; or (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 46)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the company is a private company that does not fall within the reporting exemption for the financial year, and a special resolution is passed by the members to the effect that the company is not to prepare a business review required by that Schedule for the financial year.

subsection.leadIn: A resolution for the purposes of subsection (3)(c)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: may be passed in relation to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a financial year; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a financial year and every subsequent financial year;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be passed at least 6 months before the end of the financial year to which the directors’ report relates; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: may only be revoked by a special resolution.

subsection.content: Subsections (1), (2) and (3) have effect subject to section 389.
A director of a company who fails to take all reasonable steps to secure compliance with subsection (1) or (2) commits an offence and is liable to a fine of $150,000.

A director of a company who wilfully fails to take all reasonable steps to secure compliance with subsection (1) or (2) commits an offence and is liable to a fine of $150,000 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: If a person is charged with an offence under subsection (6), it is a defence to establish that the person had reasonable grounds to believe, and did believe, that a competent and reliable person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: was charged with the duty of ensuring that subsection (1) or (2) (as the case may be) was complied with; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: was in a position to discharge that duty.

section.name: s389
section.heading: Provisions supplementary to section 388

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if at any time during a financial year of a private company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the company registers any transfer of shares in the company in contravention of the restrictions imposed by the company’s articles;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the membership of the company exceeds the number specified in section 11(1)(a)(ii); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the company makes an invitation to the public to subscribe for any shares or debentures of the company.

subsection.content: The directors’ report for the financial year is required to comply with section 388 as if the company were a public company.
The Court may, on the application of the company or a person interested in the matter, order that subsections (1) and (2) do not apply.
The Court may make the order on any terms and conditions that the Court thinks just and expedient.

subsection.leadIn: The Court must not make the order unless the Court is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the occurrence of the event mentioned in subsection (1)(a), (b) or (c) was accidental;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it was due to inadvertence or to some other sufficient cause that the event occurred; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: it is just and equitable to grant the relief on other grounds.

section.name: s390
section.heading: Contents of directors’ report: general

subsection.leadIn: A directors’ report for a financial year must contain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the name of every person who was a director of the company—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: during the financial year; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: during the period beginning with the end of the financial year and ending on the date of the report; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the principal activities of the company in the course of the financial year.

subsection.leadIn: A directors’ report must contain particulars of any other matter—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that is material for the members’ appreciation of the state of the company’s affairs; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the disclosure of which will not, in the directors’ opinion, be harmful to the business of the company.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4), this section has effect in relation to a directors’ report required to be prepared under section 388(2) as if a reference to the company in subsection (1) or (2) were a reference to— (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 47)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the subsidiary undertakings included in the annual consolidated financial statements for the financial year.

subsection.leadIn: If both of the conditions specified in subsection (5) are satisfied, this section has effect in relation to a directors’ report required to be prepared under section 388(2) as if a reference to the company in subsections (1)(b) and (2) were a reference to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the subsidiary undertakings included in the annual consolidated financial statements for the financial year. (Added 35 of 2018 s. 47)

subsection.leadIn: The conditions are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the company is a holding company of a subsidiary undertaking at the end of the financial year; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: subsection (6) is complied with in respect of a list of the name of every person who was a director of the subsidiary undertaking—

subparagraph.content: during the financial year; or
during the period beginning with the end of the financial year and ending on the date of the report. (Added 35 of 2018 s. 47)

subsection.leadIn: The list of the names—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: must, throughout the period specified in subsection (7), be—

subparagraph.content: kept at the company’s registered office; and
made available for inspection by the members free of charge during business hours; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be made available on the company’s website throughout that period. (Added 35 of 2018 s. 47)

subsection.leadIn: The period is one that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: begins on the expiry of the day on which the company sends or provides a copy of the directors’ report to the members in accordance with section 430 or 612(1)(b); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: ends on the day on which a copy of the directors’ report for the subsequent financial year is sent or provided to the members in accordance with section 430 or 612(1)(b). (Added 35 of 2018 s. 47)

section.name: s391
section.heading: Directors’ report to be approved and signed

subsection.leadIn: A directors’ report—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be approved by the directors; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be signed on the directors’ behalf by a director or by the company secretary.

subsection.content: Every copy of a directors’ report laid before a company in general meeting under section 429, or sent to a member under section 430 or otherwise circulated, published or issued by the company, must state the name of the person who signed the report on the directors’ behalf.

If, as respects any directors’ report a copy of which is circulated, published or issued by the company, subsection (1) is contravened, the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 4.
If subsection (2) is contravened, the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 4.

section.name: s392
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Division—

def.name: AppointmentPeriod
def.leadIn: appointment period (委任期), in relation to a financial year, means the period of 28 days beginning on whichever is the earlier of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date on which a copy of the reporting documents for the previous financial year is sent or provided to every member of the company under section 430(3) or 612(1)(b) (as the case may be);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the last date on which a copy of the reporting documents for the previous financial year must be sent or provided to every member of the company under section 430(3) or 612(1)(b) (as the case may be);

section.def: cessation statement (停任陳述) means a statement given under section 422(1), (2) or (3) or 423(2)(a);
practice unit (執業單位) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Accounting and Financial Reporting Council Ordinance (Cap. 588); (Amended L.N. 66 of 2022)
statement of circumstance (情況陳述) means a statement given under section 424(a) or 425(1)(a).

section.name: s393
section.heading: Eligibility for appointment

subsection.content: Only a practice unit is eligible for appointment as auditor of a company under this Subdivision.

subsection.leadIn: The following are disqualified for appointment as auditor of a company under this Subdivision—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person who is an officer or employee of the company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person who is a partner or employee of a person mentioned in paragraph (a);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: a person who—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is, by virtue of paragraph (a) or (b), disqualified for appointment as auditor of any other undertaking that is a subsidiary undertaking, or a parent undertaking, of the company or is a subsidiary undertaking of that parent undertaking; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: would be so disqualified if the undertaking were a company.

subsection.content: In this section, a reference to an officer or employee of a company excludes an auditor of the company.

section.name: s394
section.heading: Auditor must be appointed for each financial year

subsection.content: An auditor must be appointed for each financial year of a company.
An auditor may be appointed only under this Subdivision.

section.name: s395
section.heading: Appointment of first auditor by directors

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a company formed and registered under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a company formed and registered under a provision of the predecessor Ordinance having a continuing effect under Schedule 11 or by virtue of section 23 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1); and (Amended 14 of 2025 s. 32)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a re-domiciled company. (Added 14 of 2025 s. 32)

subsection.content: If the company is required to hold an annual general meeting in accordance with section 610 in respect of its first financial year, the directors may appoint the auditor of the company for that first financial year at any time before the annual general meeting.

If, by virtue of section 612(1) or (2), the company is not required to hold an annual general meeting in accordance with section 610 in respect of its first financial year, the directors may appoint the auditor of the company for that first financial year at any time before the appointment period in relation to the next financial year.

section.name: s396
section.heading: Appointment of auditor by company members

subsection.content: A company must appoint the auditor of the company for a financial year by a resolution passed at the annual general meeting held in respect of the previous financial year.

Subsection (1) does not apply to a company that, by virtue of section 612(2), is not required to hold an annual general meeting in accordance with section 610 in respect of the previous financial year.

subsection.leadIn: A company must appoint the auditor of the company for a financial year by a resolution passed at a general meeting if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by virtue of section 612(2), it is not required to hold an annual general meeting in accordance with section 610 in respect of the previous financial year; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no person is deemed to be reappointed as auditor of the company for the financial year under section 403.

subsection.content: An appointment under subsection (3) must be made before the end of the appointment period in relation to the financial year.

If, at the annual general meeting held in respect of the previous financial year, a company has not appointed the auditor of the company for a financial year, the company must make the appointment by a resolution passed at another general meeting.

A company to which section 395 applies may, by a resolution passed at a general meeting, appoint the auditor of the company for its first financial year if the directors have not done so under that section.

section.name: s397
section.heading: Appointment to fill casual vacancy

subsection.content: The directors may appoint a person to fill a casual vacancy in the office of auditor of the company.
If the directors have not done so within one month after the casual vacancy occurs, the members may, by a resolution passed at a general meeting, appoint a person to fill the casual vacancy.

section.name: s398
section.heading: Appointment of auditor by Court

subsection.leadIn: The Court may, on application by a member of a company, appoint the auditor of the company for a financial year if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a company required to hold an annual general meeting in accordance with section 610 in respect of the previous financial year—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: at the annual general meeting, no person has been appointed as auditor of the company for the financial year; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an annual general meeting has not been held in accordance with that section; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a company not required to hold an annual general meeting in accordance with section 610 in respect of the previous financial year by virtue of section 612(2)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: at the end of the appointment period in relation to the financial year, no person has been appointed as auditor of the company for the financial year; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: no person is deemed to be reappointed as auditor of the company for the financial year under section 403.

subsection.content: The Court may, on application by a member of a company to which section 395 applies, appoint the auditor of the company for its first financial year if an appointment has not been made under sections 395(2) or (3) and 396(6).
The Court may, on application by a member of a company, appoint a person to fill a casual vacancy in the office of auditor of the company if an appointment has not been made under section 397.

section.name: s399
section.heading: Effect of appointing a firm as auditor
section.leadIn: If a firm is appointed, by the firm name, as auditor of a company, the appointment is to be regarded as an appointment of those persons who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: are the partners in the firm from time to time during the currency of the appointment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: are eligible, and not disqualified, for appointment as auditor of the company under this Subdivision.

section.name: s400
section.heading: Special notice required for resolution for appointing auditor in some cases

subsection.leadIn: Special notice is required for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a resolution proposed for the purposes of section 396(1), (3) or (5) for appointing a person as auditor in place of a specified incumbent; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a resolution proposed for the purposes of section 397(2).

subsection.statutoryNote:
Note—
See also section 578 which sets out the requirements regarding special notice.

subsection.content: Special notice is also required for a resolution proposed for the purposes of section 396(1), (3) or (5) for appointing a specified incumbent as auditor if that incumbent holds office by virtue of an appointment by the directors to fill a casual vacancy under section 397(1).

subsection.leadIn: On receipt of a special notice, the company must send a copy of it—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to the person proposed to be appointed as auditor; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a proposed appointment under section 396(1), (3) or (5) of a person in place of a specified incumbent, to that incumbent; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a proposed appointment under section 396(1), (3) or (5) of a specified incumbent who holds office by virtue of an appointment under section 397(1) or (2) to fill a casual vacancy caused by a resignation, to the person who resigned.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: SpecifiedIncumbent
def.leadIn: specified incumbent (指明在任人) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person who is the last auditor of the company and whose term of office as auditor has expired; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the person whose term of office as auditor will expire—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: at the end of the general meeting; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: at the end of the appointment period in relation to the financial year concerned.

section.name: s401
section.heading: Copies of written resolution for appointment must be sent to new and old auditors

subsection.content: This section applies if an appointment of an auditor specified in subsection (2) is proposed to be effected by a written resolution of the members of a company.

subsection.leadIn: The appointment is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an appointment under section 396(1), (3) or (5) of a person in place of a specified incumbent; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an appointment under section 396(1), (3) or (5) of a specified incumbent who holds office by virtue of an appointment under section 397(1) or (2) to fill a casual vacancy caused by a resignation.

subsection.leadIn: On receipt of a copy of the proposed resolution, the company must send a copy of it—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to the person proposed to be appointed as auditor; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: subsection (2)(a), to the specified incumbent; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: subsection (2)(b), to the person who resigned.

subsection.content: If a company contravenes subsection (3), the written resolution is ineffective.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: SpecifiedIncumbent
def.leadIn: specified incumbent (指明在任人) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person who is the last auditor of the company and whose term of office as auditor has expired; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person whose term of office as auditor will expire at the end of the appointment period in relation to the financial year concerned.

section.name: s402
section.heading: Terms of office of auditor

subsection.content: A person appointed as auditor of a company holds office in accordance with the terms of the appointment.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person appointed as auditor of a company does not take office until the previous auditor’s appointment is terminated; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a person appointed as auditor of a company for a financial year under section 395, 396, 397 or 398 holds office until—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: if the company holds an annual general meeting in accordance with section 610 in respect of the financial year, the end of the annual general meeting;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if, by virtue of section 612(1), the company does not hold an annual general meeting in accordance with section 610 in respect of the financial year, the date of the written resolution passed for the purposes of section 612(1); or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: if, by virtue of section 612(2), the company does not hold an annual general meeting in accordance with section 610 in respect of the financial year, the end of the appointment period in relation to the next financial year.

section.name: s403
section.heading: Person deemed to be reappointed as auditor

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by virtue of section 612(2), a company is not required to hold an annual general meeting in accordance with section 610 in respect of a financial year; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at the end of the appointment period in relation to the next financial year, no person has been appointed as auditor of the company for that next financial year,

subsection.continued: the person who is the auditor of the company as at the end of that appointment period is deemed to be reappointed, at that time, as auditor of the company for that next financial year on the same terms of appointment.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (1), the person is not deemed to be reappointed as auditor of the company for the next financial year if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person was appointed as auditor under section 395 or 397(1);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the company’s articles require an actual appointment;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: before the person is deemed to be reappointed under that subsection, the members have by a resolution passed at a general meeting resolved that the person should not be reappointed as auditor for that next financial year;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the person declines the reappointment in a written notice sent to the company at least 14 days before the end of the appointment period in relation to that next financial year; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: members representing at least the requisite percentage of the voting rights of all the members who would be entitled to vote on a resolution that the person should not be reappointed give the company a notice complying with subsection (5).

subsection.content: Special notice is required for a resolution proposed for the purposes of subsection (2)(c).
subsection.statutoryNote:
Note—
See also section 578 which sets out the requirements regarding special notice.

subsection.content: On receipt of a special notice, the company must send a copy of it to the person proposed not to be reappointed.

subsection.leadIn: A notice for the purposes of subsection (2)(e)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must state that the person should not be reappointed;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be authenticated by the member or members giving it;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must be delivered to the company in hard copy form or electronic form; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: must be received by the company before the end of the accounting reference period immediately preceding the time when the reappointment would have effect.

subsection.content: This section does not affect the operation of Subdivision 6.

In ascertaining the amount of any compensation or damages payable to a person on ceasing to hold office of auditor for any reason, no account is to be taken of any loss of the opportunity of being deemed to be reappointed as auditor under this section.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: requisite percentage (所需百分比) means 5%, or a lower percentage specified for the purposes of this section in the company’s articles.

section.name: s404
section.heading: Auditor’s remuneration

subsection.leadIn: The remuneration of an auditor of a company appointed by the members may be fixed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by a resolution passed at a general meeting; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the manner specified in such a resolution.

subsection.leadIn: The remuneration of an auditor of a company appointed by the directors—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be fixed by the directors when making the appointment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if it has not been fixed by the directors, may be fixed—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: by a resolution passed at a general meeting; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the manner specified in such a resolution.

subsection.leadIn: The remuneration of an auditor of a company appointed by the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be fixed by the Court when making the appointment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if it has not been fixed by the Court, may be fixed—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: by a resolution passed at a general meeting; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the manner specified in such a resolution.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: remuneration (酬金), in relation to an auditor of a company, includes any sum paid by the company in respect of the expenses of the auditor.

section.name: s405
section.heading: Auditor’s duty to report
section.content: A company’s auditor must prepare a report for the members on any financial statements prepared by the directors, a copy of which is laid before the company in general meeting under section 429, or is sent to a member under section 430 or otherwise circulated, published or issued by the company, during the auditor’s term of office.

section.name: s406
section.heading: Auditor’s opinion on financial statements, directors’ report, etc.

subsection.leadIn: An auditor’s report must state, in the auditor’s opinion—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether the financial statements have been properly prepared in compliance with this Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in particular, whether the financial statements—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the case of annual financial statements of a company that does not fall within the reporting exemption for the financial year, give a true and fair view of the financial position and financial performance of the company as required by section 380; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of annual consolidated financial statements of a company that does not fall within the reporting exemption for the financial year, give a true and fair view of the financial position and financial performance of the company and all the subsidiary undertakings as required by section 380.

subsection.leadIn: If a company’s auditor is of the opinion that the information in a directors’ report for a financial year is not consistent with the financial statements for the financial year, the auditor—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must state that opinion in the auditor’s report; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may bring that opinion to the members’ attention at a general meeting.

section.name: s407
section.heading: Auditor’s opinion on other matters

subsection.leadIn: In preparing an auditor’s report, the auditor must carry out an investigation that will enable the auditor to form an opinion as to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether adequate accounting records have been kept by the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether the financial statements are in agreement with the accounting records.

subsection.leadIn: A company’s auditor must state the auditor’s opinion in the auditor’s report if the auditor is of the opinion that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: adequate accounting records have not been kept by the company; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the financial statements are not in agreement with the accounting records in any material respect.

subsection.content: If a company’s auditor fails to obtain all the information or explanations that, to the best of the auditor’s knowledge and belief, are necessary and material for the purpose of the audit, the auditor must state that fact in the auditor’s report.

If the financial statements do not comply with section 383(1), the auditor must include in the auditor’s report, so far as the auditor is reasonably able to do so, a statement giving the particulars that are required to be, but have not been, contained in the financial statements.

section.name: s408
section.heading: Offences relating to contents of auditor’s report

subsection.content: Every person specified in subsection (2) commits an offence if the person knowingly or recklessly causes a statement required to be contained in an auditor’s report under section 407(2)(b) or (3) to be omitted from the report.

subsection.leadIn: The persons are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the auditor who prepares the auditor’s report is a natural person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the auditor; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: every employee and agent of the auditor who is eligible for appointment as auditor of the company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the auditor who prepares the auditor’s report is a firm, every partner, employee and agent of the auditor who is eligible for appointment as auditor of the company; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the auditor who prepares the auditor’s report is a body corporate, every officer, member, employee and agent of the auditor who is eligible for appointment as auditor of the company.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable to a fine of $150,000.

section.name: s409
section.heading: Auditor’s reports to be signed

subsection.leadIn: An auditor’s report must be signed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the auditor is a natural person, by the auditor; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the auditor is a firm or body corporate, by a natural person authorized to sign the auditor’s name on the auditor’s behalf.

subsection.content: An auditor’s report must state the auditor’s name.

Every copy of an auditor’s report laid before a company in general meeting under section 429, or sent to a member under section 430 or otherwise circulated, published or issued by the company, must state the auditor’s name.
If subsection (3) is contravened, the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 4.

section.name: s410
section.heading: Qualified privileges

subsection.content: In the absence of malice, an auditor of a company is not liable to any action for defamation at the suit of any person in respect of any statement made by the auditor in the course of performing duties as auditor of the company.

subsection.leadIn: In the absence of malice, a person is not liable to any action for defamation at the suit of any person in respect of the publication of any document—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prepared by an auditor of a company in the course of performing duties as auditor of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: required by this Ordinance—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to be delivered to the Registrar; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to be sent to any member of the company or any other person.

subsection.content: This section does not limit or affect any other right, privilege or immunity that an auditor of a company, or any other person, has as defendant in an action for defamation.

subsection.leadIn: In this section, a reference to performing duties as auditor of a company includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: making a cessation statement, giving the statement to the company, and requesting the company to comply with the requirement specified in section 422(5) in relation to the statement; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: making a statement of circumstances, and giving the statement to the company.

section.name: s411
section.heading: Rights in relation to general meeting

subsection.leadIn: A person appointed as auditor of a company is entitled—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to attend any of the company’s general meetings; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to be heard, at any of the company’s general meetings, on any part of the business of the meeting that concerns the person as auditor of the company.

subsection.content: A person’s entitlement under subsection (1)(a) or (b) is, if the person is a firm or body corporate, exercisable by a natural person authorized by the person to act as the person’s representative at the meeting.

section.name: s412
section.heading: Rights in relation to information

subsection.content: An auditor of a company has a right of access to the company’s accounting records.

An auditor of a company may require a person that is a related entity of the company, or was a related entity of the company at the time to which the information or explanation relates, to provide the auditor with any information or explanation that the auditor reasonably requires for the performance of the duties as auditor of the company.
If an auditor has required a person to provide any information or explanation under subsection (2), the person must provide the information or explanation as soon as practicable after being required.

If a subsidiary undertaking of a company is neither a company incorporated in Hong Kong nor a re-domiciled company, an auditor of the company may require the company to obtain from any of the persons specified in subsection (5) any information or explanation that the auditor reasonably requires for the performance of the duties as auditor of the company. (Amended 14 of 2025 s. 33)

subsection.leadIn: The persons are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the subsidiary undertaking;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a person who—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is an officer or auditor of the subsidiary undertaking; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: was an officer or auditor of the subsidiary undertaking at the time to which the information or explanation relates; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: a person who—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: holds or is accountable for any of the subsidiary undertaking’s accounting records; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: held or was accountable for the subsidiary undertaking’s accounting records at the time to which the information or explanation relates.

subsection.content: If an auditor has required a company to obtain any information or explanation from a person under subsection (4), the company must take all reasonable steps to obtain the information or explanation as soon as practicable after being required.

A statement made by a person in response to a requirement under subsection (2) or (4) may not be used in evidence against the person in any criminal proceedings except proceedings for an offence under section 413.
This section does not compel a person to disclose information in respect of which a claim to legal professional privilege could be maintained in legal proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: Officer
def.leadIn: officer (高級人員), in relation to a subsidiary undertaking that is not a body corporate, means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a member of the governing body of the undertaking; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other person involved in the management of the undertaking; (Added 35 of 2018 s. 49)

def.name: RelatedEntity
def.leadIn: related entity (有關連實體), in relation to a company, means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an officer of the company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a subsidiary undertaking of the company that is a company incorporated in Hong Kong or a re-domiciled company; (Amended 14 of 2025 s. 33)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an officer or auditor of such a subsidiary undertaking; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a person holding or accountable for any of the accounting records of the company or such a subsidiary undertaking.

section.name: s413
section.heading: Offences relating to section 412

subsection.content: A person who contravenes section 412(3) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $700 for each day during which the offence continues.
If a person is charged with an offence under subsection (1), it is a defence to establish that it was not reasonably practicable for the person to provide the information or explanation.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person makes a statement to an auditor of a company that conveys or purports to convey any information or explanation that the auditor requires, or is entitled to require, under section 412(2) or (4);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the statement is misleading, false or deceptive in a material particular; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person knows that, or is reckless as to whether or not, the statement is misleading, false or deceptive in a material particular.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (3) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $150,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: If a company contravenes section 412(6), the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $700 for each day during which the offence continues.

subsection.leadIn: If a person is charged with an offence under subsection (5) for failing to obtain any information or explanation from a subsidiary undertaking or another person, it is a defence to establish that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it would be an offence under the law of a place outside Hong Kong for the subsidiary undertaking or that other person to provide the information or explanation to the defendant; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the subsidiary undertaking or that other person did not provide the information or explanation to the defendant on that ground.

subsection.content: This section does not affect an auditor’s right to apply for an injunction to enforce any of the auditor’s rights under section 412.

section.name: s414
section.heading: Auditor may provide information to incoming auditor without contravening duties

subsection.leadIn: A person who is or has been an auditor of a company does not contravene any duty owed by the person as such auditor in law by reason only that the person gives workrelated information to another person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who is an auditor of the company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: who has been appointed as auditor of the company but whose term of office has not yet begun; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to whom the company has offered the position as auditor but who has not yet been appointed.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply unless the person who gives work-related information to another person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: does so in good faith; and

paragraph.name: b
