subsection.leadIn: A company is not required to circulate a statement mentioned in section 551(2) if, on an application by the company or another person who claims to be aggrieved, the Court is satisfied that the rights given by that section are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: being abused; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: being used to secure needless publicity for defamatory matter.

subsection.content: The Court may order the members who requested the circulation of the statement to pay the whole or part of the company’s costs on an application under subsection (1), even if they are not parties to the application.

section.name: s555
section.heading: Company’s duty to notify auditor of proposed written resolution

subsection.leadIn: If a company is required to send a resolution to a member of the company under section 553, it must, on or before the circulation date, send to the auditor of the company (if more than one auditor, to each of them)— (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 59)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a copy of the resolution; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a copy of any other document relating to the resolution that is required to be sent to a member of the company under that section.

subsection.content: The copies may be sent to the auditor or auditors of the company in hard copy form or in electronic form.
If a company contravenes subsection (1), the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 3.
The validity of the resolution, if passed, is not affected by a contravention of subsection (1).

section.name: s556
section.heading: Procedure for signifying agreement to proposed written resolution

subsection.content: A written resolution is passed when all eligible members have signified their agreement to it.

subsection.leadIn: A member signifies agreement to a proposed written resolution when the company receives from the member (or from someone acting on the member’s behalf) a document—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: identifying the resolution to which it relates; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: indicating the member’s agreement to the resolution.

subsection.leadIn: The document—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be sent to the company in hard copy form or in electronic form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be authenticated by the member or by someone acting on the member’s behalf.

subsection.content: A member’s agreement to a written resolution, once signified, may not be revoked.

section.name: s557
section.heading: Agreement signified by eligible members who are joint holders of shares

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: 2 or more eligible members are joint holders of shares of a company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any holder has signified their agreement to a proposed written resolution; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the company has received, before the end of the period mentioned in section 558(1), any objection to the proposed written resolution from any other holder, the holder who has signified the agreement is more senior than the holder who has made the objection,

subsection.continued: then the other joint holder or holders are to be regarded as having signified their agreement to the proposed written resolution for the purposes of section 556(1).

subsection.content: For the purposes of this section, the seniority of a holder of a share is determined by the order in which the names of the joint holders appear in the register of members of the company.
Subsections (1) and (2) have effect subject to any provision of the company’s articles.

section.name: s558
section.heading: Period for agreeing to proposed written resolution

subsection.leadIn: A proposed written resolution lapses if it is not passed before the end of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the period specified for this purpose in the company’s articles; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if none is specified, the period of 28 days beginning on the circulation date.

subsection.content: The agreement of a member to a proposed written resolution is ineffective if signified after the end of that period.

section.name: s559
section.heading: Company’s duty to notify members and auditor that written resolution has been passed

subsection.leadIn: If a resolution of a company is passed as a written resolution, the company must, within 15 days after the resolution is passed, send a notice of this fact to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: every member of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the auditor of the company (if more than one auditor, to each of them). (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 60)

subsection.content: If a company contravenes subsection (1), the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 3.

section.name: s560
section.heading: Sending document relating to written resolution by electronic means
section.content: If a company has given an electronic address in any document containing or accompanying a proposed written resolution, it is to be regarded as having agreed that any document or information relating to that resolution may be sent by electronic means to that address (subject to any conditions or limitations specified in the document).

section.name: s561
section.heading: Relationship between this Subdivision and provisions of company’s articles

subsection.content: A provision of a company’s articles is void in so far as it would have the effect that a resolution that is required by or otherwise provided for in an Ordinance could not be proposed and passed as a written resolution.
Nothing in this Subdivision affects any provision of a company’s articles authorizing the company to pass a resolution without a meeting, otherwise than in accordance with this Subdivision.
Subsection (2) applies only if the resolution has been agreed to by all the members of the company who are entitled to vote on the resolution.

section.name: s562
section.heading: General provisions

subsection.leadIn: A resolution of a company is validly passed at a general meeting if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: notice of the meeting and of the resolution is given;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the meeting is held and conducted; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the resolution is passed,

subsection.continued: in accordance with this Subdivision and Subdivisions 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 and 9 (and, if relevant, Subdivision 10) and the company’s articles.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (1), if there is any inconsistency between a provision of a Subdivision referred to in that subsection, and a provision of the company’s articles, unless otherwise provided in or in respect of that Subdivision, the provision of that Subdivision prevails over the provision of the articles to the extent of the inconsistency.

subsection.leadIn: If a provision of any Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: requires or otherwise provides for a resolution of a company, or of the members (or of a class of members) of a company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: does not specify what kind of resolution is required,

subsection.continued: what is required is an ordinary resolution unless the company’s articles require a higher majority (or unanimity).

section.name: s563
section.heading: Ordinary resolution

subsection.content: An ordinary resolution of the members (or of a class of members) of a company means a resolution that is passed by a simple majority.

subsection.leadIn: A resolution passed at a general meeting on a show of hands is passed by a simple majority if it is passed by a simple majority of the total of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the number of the members who (being entitled to do so) vote in person on the resolution;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the number of the persons who vote on the resolution as duly appointed proxies of members entitled to vote on it.

subsection.content: A resolution passed on a poll taken at a general meeting is passed by a simple majority if it is passed by members representing a simple majority of the total voting rights of all the members who (being entitled to do so) vote in person or by proxy on the resolution.
Anything that may be done by an ordinary resolution may also be done by a special resolution.

section.name: s564
section.heading: Special resolution

subsection.content: A special resolution of the members (or of a class of members) of a company means a resolution that is passed by a majority of at least 75%.

subsection.leadIn: A resolution passed at a general meeting on a show of hands is passed by a majority of at least 75% if it is passed by at least 75% of the total of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the number of the members who (being entitled to do so) vote in person on the resolution;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the number of the persons who vote on the resolution as duly appointed proxies of members entitled to vote on it.

subsection.content: A resolution passed on a poll taken at a general meeting is passed by a majority of at least 75% if it is passed by members representing at least 75% of the total voting rights of all the members who (being entitled to do so) vote in person or by proxy on the resolution.

subsection.leadIn: If a resolution is passed at a general meeting—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the resolution is not a special resolution unless the notice of the meeting included the text of the resolution and specified the intention to propose the resolution as a special resolution; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the notice of the meeting so specified, the resolution may only be passed as a special resolution.

subsection.leadIn: A reference to an extraordinary resolution of a company or of a meeting of any class of members of a company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: contained in any Ordinance that was enacted or document that existed before 31 August 1984; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: deemed, in relation to a resolution passed or to be passed on or after that date, to be a special resolution of the company or meeting under section 116(5) of the predecessor Ordinance,

subsection.continued: continues to be deemed to be such a special resolution of the company or meeting.

section.name: s565
section.heading: Directors’ power to call general meeting
section.content: The directors of a company may call a general meeting of the company.

section.name: s566
section.heading: Members’ power to request directors to call general meeting

subsection.content: The members of a company may request the directors to call a general meeting of the company.

The directors are required to call a general meeting if the company has received requests to do so from members of the company representing at least 5% of the total voting rights of all the members having a right to vote at general meetings.

subsection.leadIn: A request—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must state the general nature of the business to be dealt with at the meeting; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may include the text of a resolution that may properly be moved and is intended to be moved at the meeting.

subsection.content: Requests may consist of several documents in like form.

subsection.leadIn: A request—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be sent to the company in hard copy form or in electronic form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be authenticated by the person or persons making it.

section.name: s567
section.heading: Directors’ duty to call general meeting requested by members

subsection.content: Directors required under section 566 to call a general meeting must call a meeting within 21 days after the date on which they become subject to the requirement.
A meeting called under subsection (1) must be held on a date not more than 28 days after the date of the notice convening the meeting.
If the requests received by the company identify a resolution that may properly be moved and is intended to be moved at the meeting, the notice of the meeting must include notice of the resolution.
The business that may be dealt with at the meeting includes a resolution of which notice has been included in the notice of meeting in accordance with subsection (3).

If the resolution is to be proposed as a special resolution, the directors are to be regarded as not having duly called the meeting unless the notice of the meeting includes the text of the resolution and specifies the intention to propose the resolution as a special resolution.

section.name: s568
section.heading: Members’ power to call general meeting at company’s expense

subsection.leadIn: If the directors—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: are required under section 566 to call a general meeting; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: do not do so in accordance with section 567,

subsection.continued: the members who requested the meeting, or any of them representing more than one half of the total voting rights of all of them, may themselves call a general meeting.

subsection.content: If the requests received by the company identify a resolution that may properly be moved and is intended to be moved at the meeting, the notice of the meeting must include notice of the resolution.
The meeting must be called for a date not more than 3 months after the date on which the directors become subject to the requirement to call a meeting.
The meeting must be called in the same manner, as nearly as possible, as that in which that meeting is required to be called by the directors of the company.
The business that may be dealt with at the meeting includes a resolution of which notice has been included in the notice of meeting in accordance with subsection (2).
Any reasonable expenses incurred by the members requesting the meeting by reason of the failure of the directors duly to call a meeting must be reimbursed by the company.

Any sum so reimbursed must be retained by the company out of any sum due or to become due from the company by way of fees or other remuneration in respect of the services of the directors who were in default.

section.name: s569
section.heading: Members’ power to call general meeting when there is no director etc.

subsection.content: If at any time a company does not have any director or does not have sufficient directors capable of acting to form a quorum, any director, or any 2 or more members of the company representing at least 10% of the total voting rights of all the members having a right to vote at general meetings, may call a general meeting in the same manner, as nearly as possible, as that in which general meetings may be called by the directors of the company.
Subsection (1) has effect in so far as the articles of the company do not make other provision in that behalf.

section.name: s570
section.heading: Power of Court to order meeting

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if for any reason it is impracticable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to call a general meeting of a company in any manner in which general meetings of that company may be called; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to conduct the meeting in the manner prescribed by the company’s articles or this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may, either of its own motion or on application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by a director of the company; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by a member of the company who would be entitled to vote at the meeting,

subsection.continued: order a general meeting of the company to be called, held and conducted in any manner the Court thinks fit.

subsection.content: If the order is made, the Court may give any ancillary or consequential directions that it thinks expedient.
Directions given under subsection (3) may include a direction that one member of the company present at the meeting in person or by proxy is to be regarded as constituting a quorum.
A general meeting called, held and conducted in accordance with an order under subsection (2) is to be regarded for all purposes as a general meeting of the company duly called, held and conducted.

The legal personal representative of a deceased member of a company is to be regarded in all respects, for the purposes of this section, as a member of the company having the same rights with respect to attending and voting at a meeting of the company as the deceased member would, if living, have had.

section.name: s571
section.heading: Notice required of general meeting

subsection.leadIn: A general meeting of a company (other than an adjourned meeting) must be called by notice of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of an annual general meeting, at least 21 days; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in any other case—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: if the company is a limited company, at least 14 days; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if the company is an unlimited company, at least 7 days.

subsection.content: If the company’s articles require a longer period of notice than that specified in subsection (1), a general meeting of a company (other than an adjourned meeting) must be called by notice of that longer period.

subsection.leadIn: A general meeting of a company is to be regarded, despite the fact that it is called by shorter notice than that specified in subsection (1) or in the company’s articles, as having been duly called if it is so agreed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of an annual general meeting, by all the members entitled to attend and vote at the meeting; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, by a majority in number of the members having the right to attend and vote at the meeting, being a majority together representing at least 95% of the total voting rights at the meeting of all the members.

section.name: s572
section.heading: Manner in which notice to be given

subsection.leadIn: Notice of a general meeting of a company must be given—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in hard copy form or in electronic form; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by making the notice available on a website,

subsection.continued: or partly by one of those means and partly by another.

subsection.content: If a company has given an electronic address in a notice calling a meeting, it is to be regarded as having agreed that any document or information relating to proceedings at the meeting may be sent by electronic means to that address (subject to any conditions or limitations specified in the notice).

section.name: s573
section.heading: Publication of notice of general meeting on website

subsection.content: Without limiting Part 18, notice of a general meeting is not validly given by a company by making it available on a website unless it is given in accordance with this section.

subsection.leadIn: When the company notifies a member of the availability of the notice on the website, the notification must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: state that it concerns a notice of a company meeting;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify the date and time of the meeting; (Replaced 2 of 2023 s. 4)

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.leadIn: specify—

subparagraph.content: if the notice specifies only the physical venue of the meeting—the physical venue;
if the notice specifies only the virtual meeting technology to be used for holding the meeting—the virtual meeting technology; or

if the notice specifies both the physical venue of the meeting and the virtual meeting technology to be used for holding the meeting—both the physical venue and the virtual meeting technology; and (Added 2 of 2023 s. 4)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of an annual general meeting, state that it is an annual general meeting.

subsection.content: The notice must be available on the website throughout the period beginning on the date of that notification and ending on the conclusion of the meeting.

section.name: s574
section.heading: Persons entitled to receive notice of general meeting

subsection.leadIn: Notice of a general meeting of a company must be given to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: every member of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: every director.

subsection.content: In subsection (1), the reference to a member includes any person who is entitled to a share in consequence of the death or bankruptcy of a member, if the company has been notified of that person’s entitlement.
Subsections (1) and (2) have effect subject to any provision of the company’s articles.

In the case of a listed company, notice of a general meeting of the company must be given to every member not entitled to vote at the meeting at the same time and in the same manner as notice of the meeting is given to members who are so entitled.
A company is only required to comply with subsection (4) if the company is required to give notice of a general meeting of the company to members who are entitled to vote at the general meeting.

Despite subsection (4), if a meeting is called at any time by shorter notice than that specified in section 571(1) or in the company’s articles, subsection (4) is to be regarded as having been complied with if the notice required to be given under that subsection is given as soon as practicable after that time.

section.name: s575
section.heading: Duty to give notice of general meeting to auditor

subsection.content: If notice of a general meeting of a company or any other document relating to the general meeting is required to be given to a member, the company must give a copy of it to its auditor (if more than one auditor, to each of them) at the same time as the notice or the other document is given to the member. (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 61)
If a company contravenes subsection (1), the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 3.

section.name: s576
section.heading: Contents of notice of general meeting

subsection.leadIn: A company must ensure that a notice of a general meeting of the company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: specifies the date and time of the meeting;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: specifies either or both of the following—

subparagraph.content: the physical venue of the meeting;
the virtual meeting technology to be used for holding the meeting; (Replaced 2 of 2023 s. 5)

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.content: if 2 or more physical venues are specified under paragraph (b)(i)—specifies the principal venue, and the other venue or venues, of the meeting; (Added 2 of 2023 s. 5)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: states the general nature of the business to be dealt with at the meeting;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in the case of a notice calling an annual general meeting, states that the meeting is an annual general meeting; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: if a resolution is intended to be moved at the meeting—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: includes notice of the resolution; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: (where the company is not a wholly owned subsidiary) includes or is accompanied by a statement containing the information and explanation, if any, that is reasonably necessary to indicate the purpose of the resolution.

subsection.content: Subsection (1)(a), (b), (ba) and (c) has effect subject to any provision of the company’s articles. (Amended 2 of 2023 s. 5)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: To avoid doubt—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a notice of a general meeting of a company may specify the virtual meeting technology to be used for holding the meeting (whether or not the notice also specifies the physical venue of the meeting) unless—

subparagraph.content: the company’s articles expressly preclude the holding of a general meeting by using virtual meeting technology; or
the company’s articles require a general meeting to be held only at a physical venue; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purposes of paragraph (a)(ii), a provision of the company’s articles having the effect of requiring a notice of a general meeting to specify the physical venue of the meeting is not in itself a provision that requires a general meeting to be held only at a physical venue. (Added 2 of 2023 s. 5)

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1)(e) does not apply in relation to a resolution of which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: notice has been included in the notice of meeting under section 567(3) or 568(2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: notice has been given under section 615.

subsection.content: If a company contravenes subsection (1)(e), the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 3.
The validity of a resolution, if passed at a general meeting of a company, is not affected by a contravention of subsection (1)(e).
Subsection (5) does not affect any common law rules or equitable principles, or the provisions of any other Ordinance, as regards the validity of a resolution.

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (1)(e)—
subsection.def: wholly owned subsidiary (全資附屬公司) has the meaning given by section 357(3).

section.name: s577
section.heading: Explanation of improving director’s emoluments to be set out in notice of general meeting

subsection.leadIn: A company must not at a general meeting amend its articles so as to provide emoluments or improved emoluments for a director of the company in respect of the office as director unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is set out in the notice calling the meeting or in a document attached to the notice an adequate explanation of the provision; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the provision is approved by a resolution not relating also to other matters.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: Emoluments
def.leadIn: emoluments (薪酬) includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fees and percentages;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any sums paid by way of expenses allowance;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any contribution paid in respect of the director under any pension scheme; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any benefits received by the director otherwise than in cash in respect of the director’s services as director.

section.name: s578
section.heading: Resolution requiring special notice

subsection.content: If by any provision of this Ordinance special notice is required to be given of a resolution, the resolution is not effective unless notice of the intention to move it has been given to the company at least 28 days before the meeting at which it is moved.
The company must, if practicable, give its members notice of the resolution at the same time and in the same manner as it gives notice of the meeting.

subsection.leadIn: If that is not practicable, the company must give its members notice of the resolution at least 14 days before the meeting—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by advertisement in a newspaper circulating generally in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other manner allowed by the company’s articles.

subsection.content: If, after notice of the intention to move the resolution has been given to the company, a meeting is called for a date 28 days or less after the notice has been given, the notice is to be regarded as having been properly given, though not given within the time required.

section.name: s579
section.heading: Accidental omission to give notice of meeting or resolution

subsection.leadIn: If a company gives notice of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a general meeting; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a resolution intended to be moved at a general meeting,

subsection.continued: any accidental omission to give notice to, or any non-receipt of notice by, any person entitled to receive notice must be disregarded for the purpose of determining whether notice of the meeting or resolution is duly given.

subsection.content: Except in relation to notice given under section 567, 568 or 616, subsection (1) has effect subject to any provision of the company’s articles.

section.name: s580
section.heading: Members’ power to request circulation of statement

subsection.leadIn: A member of a company may request the company to circulate, to members of the company entitled to receive notice of a general meeting, a statement of not more than 1 000 words with respect to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a matter mentioned in a proposed resolution to be dealt with at that meeting; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: other business to be dealt with at that meeting.

subsection.leadIn: However, each member may only request the company to circulate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: one such statement with respect to the resolution mentioned in subsection (1)(a); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: one such statement with respect to the other business mentioned in subsection (1)(b).

subsection.leadIn: A company is required to circulate the statement if it has received requests to do so from—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: members representing at least 2.5% of the total voting rights of all the members who have a relevant right to vote; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at least 50 members who have a relevant right to vote.

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (3)—

def.name: RelevantRightToVote
def.leadIn: relevant right to vote (相關表決權利) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to a statement with respect to a matter mentioned in a proposed resolution, a right to vote on that resolution at the meeting to which the requests relate; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to any other statement, a right to vote at the meeting to which the requests relate.

subsection.leadIn: A request under subsection (3)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be sent to the company in hard copy form or in electronic form;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must identify the statement to be circulated;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must be authenticated by the person or persons making it; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: must be received by the company at least 7 days before the meeting to which it relates.

section.name: s581
section.heading: Company’s duty to circulate members’ statement

subsection.leadIn: A company that is required under section 580 to circulate a statement must send a copy of it to each member of the company entitled to receive notice of the meeting—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the same manner as the notice of the meeting; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at the same time as, or as soon as reasonably practicable after, it gives notice of the meeting.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) has effect subject to sections 582(2) and 583.
If a company contravenes subsection (1), the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 5.

section.name: s582
section.heading: Expenses of circulating members’ statement

subsection.leadIn: The expenses of the company in complying with section 581 need not be paid by the members who requested the circulation of the statement if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the meeting to which the requests relate is an annual general meeting of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: requests sufficient to require the company to circulate the statement are received in time to enable the company to send a copy of the statement at the same time as it gives notice of the meeting.

subsection.leadIn: Otherwise—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the expenses of the company in complying with section 581 must be paid by the members who requested the circulation of the statement unless the company resolves otherwise; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: unless the company has previously so resolved, it is not bound to comply with that section unless there is deposited with or tendered to it, not later than 7 days before the meeting, a sum reasonably sufficient to meet its expenses in doing so.

section.name: s583
section.heading: Application not to circulate members’ statement

subsection.leadIn: A company is not required to circulate a statement under section 581 if, on an application by the company or another person who claims to be aggrieved, the Court is satisfied that the rights given by section 580 are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: being abused; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: being used to secure needless publicity for defamatory matter.

subsection.content: The Court may order the members who requested the circulation of the statement to pay the whole or part of the company’s costs on an application under subsection (1), even if they are not parties to the application.

section.name: s583A
section.heading: Mode of holding general meeting

subsection.leadIn: A company may hold a general meeting—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at a physical venue;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by using virtual meeting technology; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: both at a physical venue and by using virtual meeting technology.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) has effect subject to any provision of the company’s articles.

subsection.leadIn: To avoid doubt—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a company may hold a general meeting by using virtual meeting technology (whether or not also at a physical venue) unless—

subparagraph.content: the company’s articles expressly preclude the holding of a general meeting by using virtual meeting technology; or
the company’s articles require a general meeting to be held only at a physical venue; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purposes of paragraph (a)(ii), a provision of the company’s articles having the effect of requiring a notice of a general meeting to specify the physical venue of the meeting is not in itself a provision that requires a general meeting to be held only at a physical venue.

section.name: s584
section.heading: Meeting at 2 or more physical venues

subsection.content: If a general meeting of a company is held at 2 or more physical venues (whether or not also by using the virtual meeting technology specified in the notice of the meeting), the company must use any technology that allows the members of the company who are not together at the same physical venue to listen, speak and vote at the meeting. (Replaced 2 of 2023 s. 7)
Subsection (1) has effect subject to any provision of the company’s articles.

section.name: s585
section.heading: Quorum at meeting

subsection.content: If a company has only one member, that member present in person or by proxy is a quorum of a general meeting of the company.
If that member of the company is a body corporate, that member present by its corporate representative is also a quorum of a general meeting of the company.
Subject to subsection (1) and the provisions of a company’s articles, 2 members present in person or by proxy is a quorum of a general meeting of the company.
If a member of the company is a body corporate, that member present by its corporate representative counts towards a quorum of a general meeting of the company.

subsection.name: 4A
subsection.content: For the purposes of this section, a person who attends a general meeting by using the virtual meeting technology specified in the notice of the meeting is to be regarded as being present while so attending. (Added 2 of 2023 s. 8)

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: corporate representative (法團代表) means a person authorized under section 606 to act as the representative of the body corporate.

section.name: s586
section.heading: Chairperson of meeting

subsection.content: A member may be elected to be the chairperson of a general meeting by a resolution of the company passed at the meeting.
Subsection (1) is subject to any provision of the company’s articles that states who may or who may not be chairperson.

section.name: s587
section.heading: Resolution passed at adjourned meeting
section.content: If a resolution is passed at an adjourned meeting of a company, the resolution is for all purposes to be regarded as having been passed on the date on which it was in fact passed, and is not to be regarded as having been passed on any earlier date.

section.name: s588
section.heading: General rules on votes

subsection.leadIn: On a vote on a resolution on a show of hands at a general meeting—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: every member present in person has one vote; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: every proxy present who has been duly appointed by a member entitled to vote on the resolution has one vote.

subsection.content: If a member appoints more than one proxy, the proxies so appointed are not entitled to vote on the resolution on a show of hands.

subsection.leadIn: On a vote on a resolution on a poll taken at a general meeting—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a company having a share capital—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: every member present in person has one vote for each share held by him or her; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: every proxy present who has been duly appointed by a member has one vote for each share in respect of which the proxy is appointed; and (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 62)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a company not having a share capital—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: every member present in person has one vote; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: every proxy present who has been duly appointed by a member entitled to vote on the resolution has one vote.

subsection.content: Subsections (1), (2) and (3) have effect subject to any provision of the company’s articles.
If any shares in a company are held in trust for the company, those shares do not, for so long as they are so held, confer any right to vote at a general meeting of the company.

section.name: s589
section.heading: Votes of joint holders of shares

subsection.content: In the case of joint holders of shares of a company, only the vote of the most senior holder who votes (and any proxies duly authorized by the holder) may be counted by the company.
For the purposes of this section, the seniority of a holder of a share is determined by the order in which the names of the joint holders appear in the register of members of the company.
Subsections (1) and (2) have effect subject to any provision of the company’s articles.

section.name: s590
section.heading: Declaration by chairperson on show of hands

subsection.leadIn: On a vote on a resolution on a show of hands at a general meeting, a declaration by the chairperson that the resolution—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has or has not been passed; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: passed by a particular majority,

subsection.continued: is conclusive evidence of that fact without proof of the number or proportion of the votes recorded in favour of or against the resolution.

subsection.content: An entry in respect of the declaration in minutes of the meeting recorded in accordance with section 618 is also conclusive evidence of that fact without the proof.
This section does not have effect if a poll is demanded in respect of the resolution before or on the declaration under subsection (1) (and the demand is not subsequently withdrawn).

section.name: s591
section.heading: Right to demand poll

subsection.leadIn: A provision of a company’s articles is void in so far as it would have the effect of excluding the right to demand a poll at a general meeting on any question other than—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the election of the chairperson of the meeting; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the adjournment of the meeting.

subsection.leadIn: A provision of a company’s articles is void in so far as it would have the effect of making ineffective a demand for a poll at a general meeting on any question other than those specified in subsection (1)(a) and (b), which is made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by at least 5 members having the right to vote at the meeting;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by a member or members representing at least 5% of the total voting rights of all the members having the right to vote at the meeting; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: by the chairperson of the meeting.

subsection.content: The appointment of a proxy to vote on a matter at a general meeting of a company authorizes the proxy to demand, or join in demanding, a poll on that matter.

subsection.leadIn: In applying subsection (2), a demand by a proxy counts—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the purposes of subsection (2)(a), as a demand by the member; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purposes of subsection (2)(b), as a demand by a member representing the voting rights that the proxy is authorized to exercise.

section.name: s592
section.heading: Chairperson’s duty to demand poll
section.content: If, before or on the declaration of the result on a show of hands at a general meeting, the chairperson of the meeting knows from the proxies received by the company that the result on a show of hands will be different from that on a poll, the chairperson must demand a poll.

section.name: s593
section.heading: Voting on poll
section.leadIn: On a poll taken at a general meeting of a company, a member entitled to more than one vote need not, if the member votes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: use all the votes; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: cast all the votes the member uses in the same way.

section.name: s594
section.heading: Company’s duty to record result of poll in minutes of general meeting

subsection.leadIn: In respect of a resolution decided on a poll taken at a general meeting of a company, the company must record in the minutes of proceedings of the general meeting—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the result of the poll;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the total number of votes that could be cast on the resolution;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the number of votes in favour of the resolution; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the number of votes against the resolution.

subsection.content: If a company contravenes subsection (1), the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 3.

section.name: s595
section.heading: Saving for provisions of articles as to determination of entitlement to vote
section.leadIn: Nothing in this Subdivision affects—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: any provision of a company’s articles—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: requiring an objection to a person’s entitlement to vote on a resolution to be made in accordance with the articles; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: for the determination of the objection to be final and conclusive; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the grounds on which such a determination may be questioned in legal proceedings.

section.name: s596
section.heading: Right to appoint proxy

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), a member of a company is entitled to appoint another person (whether a member or not) as a proxy to exercise all or any of the member’s rights to attend and to speak and vote at a general meeting of the company.

In the case of a company limited by guarantee, the company’s articles may require that a proxy must be a member of the company and if the company’s articles so require, a member of the company may only appoint another member as a proxy.

In the case of a company having a share capital, a member of the company may appoint separate proxies to represent respectively the number of the shares held by the member that is specified in their instruments of appointment.

section.name: s597
section.heading: Notice of meeting to contain statement of rights etc.

subsection.leadIn: A company must ensure that in a notice calling a general meeting of the company, there must appear, with reasonable prominence, a statement informing the member of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the rights under section 596(1) and (3); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the requirement under section 596(2).

subsection.content: If a company contravenes subsection (1), the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 3.
A contravention of subsection (1) does not affect the validity of the meeting or of anything done at the meeting.

section.name: s598
section.heading: Notice required of appointment of proxy etc.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the appointment of a proxy; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any document necessary to show the validity of, or otherwise relating to, the appointment of a proxy.

subsection.leadIn: A provision of the company’s articles is void in so far as it would have the effect of requiring the appointment or document to be received by the company or another person earlier than the following time—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a general meeting or adjourned general meeting, 48 hours before the time for holding the meeting or adjourned meeting;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a poll taken more than 48 hours after it was demanded, 24 hours before the time appointed for the taking of the poll.

subsection.content: In calculating the periods mentioned in subsection (2), no account is to be taken of any part of a day that is a public holiday.

section.name: s599
section.heading: Sending documents relating to proxies in electronic form

subsection.leadIn: If a company has given an electronic address in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an instrument of proxy issued by the company in relation to a general meeting; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an invitation to appoint a proxy issued by the company in relation to the meeting,

subsection.continued: it is to be regarded as having agreed that any document or information relating to proxies for that meeting may be sent by electronic means to that address (subject to any conditions or limitations specified in the instrument or invitation).

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (1), documents relating to proxies include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the appointment of a proxy in relation to a general meeting;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any document necessary to show the validity of, or otherwise relating to, the appointment of a proxy; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: notice of the termination of the authority of a proxy.

section.name: s600
section.heading: Company-sponsored invitations to appoint proxies

subsection.content: A company must not, for the purposes of a general meeting of the company, issue at its expense invitations to members to appoint as proxy a specified person or a number of specified persons unless the invitations are issued to all members entitled to be sent a notice of the meeting and to vote at the meeting by proxy.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) is not contravened if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is issued to a member at that member’s request a form of appointment naming the proxy or a list of persons willing to act as proxy; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the form or list is available on request to all members entitled to vote at the meeting by proxy.

subsection.content: If a company contravenes subsection (1), every responsible person of the company, commits an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 3.

section.name: s601
section.heading: Requirement as to instrument of proxy issued by company

subsection.content: This section applies to an instrument of proxy issued to a member of a company by the company for use by the member for appointing a proxy to attend and vote at a general meeting of the company.

The instrument of proxy must be such as to enable the member, according to the member’s intention, to instruct the proxy to vote in favour of or against (or, in default of instructions, to exercise the proxy’s discretion in respect of) each resolution dealing with any business to be transacted at the meeting.

section.name: s602
section.heading: Chairing meeting by proxy

subsection.content: A proxy may be elected to be the chairperson of a general meeting by a resolution of the company passed at the meeting.
Subsection (1) is subject to any provision of the company’s articles that states who may or who may not be chairperson.

section.name: s603
section.heading: Company-sponsored proxy’s duty to vote in the way specified in appointment of proxy

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to a person who is named by a company as a proxy, whether the nomination is made in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an instrument of proxy issued by the company in relation to a general meeting; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an invitation to appoint a proxy issued by the company in relation to the meeting.

subsection.leadIn: If the person has been duly appointed as a proxy by a member entitled to vote at the meeting, that person must, subject to section 588—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: vote as a proxy—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: on a show of hands; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: on a poll; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: vote in the way specified (if any) by the member in the appointment of proxy.

subsection.leadIn: If the person has been duly appointed as a proxy by 2 or more members entitled to vote at the meeting and the members specify different ways to vote in their appointment of proxy, the proxy—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must, subject to section 588(2), vote on a show of hands in the way specified by the member or members representing a simple majority of the total voting rights that the proxy is authorized to exercise at the meeting; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if there is no majority, must not vote on a show of hands.

subsection.content: A person who knowingly and wilfully contravenes subsection (2) or (3) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3.

section.name: s604
section.heading: Notice required of termination of proxy’s authority

subsection.content: This section applies to a notice that the authority of a person to act as proxy is terminated (notice of termination).

subsection.leadIn: The termination of the authority of a person to act as proxy does not affect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether there is a quorum at a general meeting (irrespective of whether the proxy has been counted in deciding the question);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the validity of anything the person does as chairperson of a general meeting; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the validity of a poll demanded by the person at a general meeting,

subsection.continued: unless the company receives notice of the termination before the commencement of the meeting.

subsection.leadIn: The termination of the authority of a person to act as proxy does not affect the validity of a vote given by that person unless the company receives notice of the termination—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: before the commencement of the meeting or adjourned meeting at which the vote is given; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a poll taken more than 48 hours after it is demanded, before the time appointed for the taking of the poll.

subsection.leadIn: If the company’s articles require or permit members to give notice of termination to a person other than the company, the references in subsections (2) and (3) to the company receiving notice have effect as if they were—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: references to that person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: references to the company or that person,

subsection.continued: as the case requires.

subsection.content: Subsections (2) and (3) have effect subject to any provision of the company’s articles that has the effect of requiring notice of termination to be received by the company or another person at a time earlier than that specified in those subsections.
Subsection (5) is subject to subsection (7).

subsection.leadIn: A provision of the company’s articles is void in so far as it would have the effect of requiring notice of termination to be received by the company or another person earlier than the following time—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a general meeting or adjourned general meeting, 48 hours before the time for holding the meeting or adjourned meeting;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a poll taken more than 48 hours after it was demanded, 24 hours before the time appointed for the taking of the poll.

subsection.content: In calculating the periods mentioned in subsections (3)(b) and (7), no account is to be taken of any part of a day that is a public holiday.

section.name: s605
section.heading: Effect of member’s voting in person on proxy’s authority

subsection.leadIn: A proxy’s authority in relation to a resolution is to be regarded as revoked if the member who has appointed the proxy—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: attends in person the general meeting at which the resolution is to be decided; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: exercises, in relation to that resolution—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the voting right attached to the shares in respect of which the proxy is appointed; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if the company does not have a share capital, the voting right the member is entitled to exercise.

subsection.content: A member who is entitled to attend, speak or vote (either on a show of hands or on a poll) at a general meeting remains so entitled in respect of that meeting or any adjournment of it, even though a valid appointment of a proxy has been delivered to the company by or on behalf of that member.

section.name: s606
section.heading: Representation of body corporate at meetings

subsection.leadIn: A body corporate may by resolution of its directors or other governing body—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if it is a member of a company, authorize any person it thinks fit to act as its representative at any meeting of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if it is a creditor (including a holder of debentures) of a company, authorize any person it thinks fit to act as its representative at any meeting of any creditors of the company held under the provisions of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: this Ordinance; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any debenture or trust deed or other instrument.

subsection.content: A person authorized under subsection (1) is entitled to exercise the same powers on behalf of the body corporate as that body corporate could exercise if it were an individual member, creditor, or holder of debentures, of the company.

section.name: s607
section.heading: Representation of recognized clearing house at meetings

subsection.content: A recognized clearing house within the meaning of section 1 of Part 1 of Schedule 1 to the Securities and Futures Ordinance (Cap. 571) may, if it or its nominee is a member of a company, authorize any person or persons it thinks fit to act as its representative or representatives, at any meeting of the company.
If more than one person is authorized under subsection (1), the authorization must specify the number and class of shares in respect of which each person is so authorized.

A person authorized under subsection (1) is entitled to exercise the same powers on behalf of the recognized clearing house (or its nominee) as that clearing house (or its nominee) could exercise if it were an individual member of the company.

section.name: s608
section.heading: Saving for more extensive rights given by articles
section.content: Nothing in this Subdivision prevents a company’s articles from giving more extensive rights to members or proxies than are given by this Subdivision.

section.name: s609
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Subdivision—
section.def: accounting reference period (會計參照期) has the meaning given by section 368.

section.name: s610
section.heading: Requirement to hold annual general meeting

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), a company must, in respect of each financial year of the company, hold a general meeting as its annual general meeting within the following period (in addition to any other meetings held during the period)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a private company or a company limited by guarantee, 9 months after the end of its accounting reference period by reference to which the financial year is to be determined; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of any other company, 6 months after the end of its accounting reference period by reference to which the financial year is to be determined.

subsection.leadIn: If the accounting reference period mentioned in subsection (1) is the first accounting reference period of the company and is longer than 12 months, the company must hold a general meeting as its annual general meeting within the following period—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a private company or a company limited by guarantee—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: 9 months after the first anniversary of the specified event; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: 3 months after the end of that accounting reference period,

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of any other company—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: 6 months after the first anniversary of the specified event; or (Amended 14 of 2025 s. 47)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: 3 months after the end of that accounting reference period,

paragraph.continued: whichever is the later. (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 63)

subsection.leadIn: If a company has by a directors’ resolution under section 371 or a notice delivered to the Registrar under that section, shortened an accounting reference period, the company must hold a general meeting as its annual general meeting within the following period—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a private company or a company limited by guarantee—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: 9 months after the end of the shortened accounting reference period; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: 3 months after the date of the directors’ resolution,

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of any other company—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: 6 months after the end of the shortened accounting reference period; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: 3 months after the date of the directors’ resolution,

subsection.content: A private company mentioned in subsections (1), (2) and (3) does not include a private company that is, at any time during the financial year, a subsidiary of a public company.

If for any reason the Court thinks fit to do so, it may, on an application made before the end of the period otherwise allowed for holding an annual general meeting in respect of a financial year of a company, by order extend that period by a further period specified in the order.

If the period otherwise allowed for holding an annual general meeting in respect of a financial year of a company has been extended under subsection (5), the company must hold a general meeting as its annual general meeting within the period as so extended.

subsection.leadIn: If a company contravenes subsection (1), (2), (3) or (6), the Court may, on application by any member of the company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: call, or direct the calling of, a general meeting of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: give any ancillary or consequential directions that the Court thinks expedient, including—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a direction modifying or supplementing, in relation to the calling, holding and conducting of the meeting, the operation of the company’s articles; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a direction that one member of the company present in person or by proxy is to be regarded as constituting a meeting.

subsection.content: Subject to any directions of the Court, a general meeting held under subsection (7) is to be regarded as an annual general meeting of the company in respect of the financial year in respect of which the company has failed to hold an annual general meeting in accordance with this section.

If a company contravenes subsection (1), (2), (3) or (6), or contravenes a direction given under subsection (7), the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 5.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: SpecifiedEvent
def.leadIn: specified event (指明事件)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to a company other than a re-domiciled company—means the incorporation of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to a re-domiciled company—means the registration of the company under section 820C(1). (Added 14 of 2025 s. 47)

section.name: s611
section.heading: Exemption of dormant company from requirement to hold annual general meeting

subsection.content: Section 610 does not apply to a company that is a dormant company under section 5(1).
If such a company enters into an accounting transaction, subsection (1) ceases to have effect on and after the date of the accounting transaction.

section.name: s612
section.heading: Circumstances in which company not required to hold annual general meeting

subsection.leadIn: A company is not required to hold an annual general meeting in accordance with section 610 if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: everything that is required or intended to be done at the meeting (by resolution or otherwise) is done by a written resolution; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a copy of each document that under this Ordinance would otherwise be required to be laid before the company at the meeting or otherwise produced at the meeting is provided to each member, on or before the circulation date of the written resolution.

subsection.leadIn: A company is also not required to hold an annual general meeting in accordance with section 610 if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the company has only one member; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: all of the following are satisfied—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the company has by resolution passed in accordance with section 613(1) dispensed with the holding of the annual general meeting;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the company has not revoked the resolution under section 614(1), or the company has revoked the resolution under that section but is not required to hold an annual general meeting under section 614(2)(b);

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: no member of the company has required the holding of the annual general meeting under section 613(5).

section.name: s613
section.heading: Dispensation with annual general meeting

subsection.content: A company may, by resolution passed in accordance with subsection (3), dispense with the holding of annual general meetings in accordance with section 610.
A resolution mentioned in subsection (1) may be passed by a written resolution or at a general meeting.

subsection.leadIn: Despite any other provision of this Ordinance, a resolution mentioned in subsection (1) is only to be regarded as passed if it has been passed by all members of the company who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: are entitled to vote on the resolution on the date of the resolution; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a written resolution, are entitled to vote on the resolution on the circulation date of the resolution.

subsection.leadIn: A resolution under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is not to have effect for the financial year in respect of which the period specified in section 610 for holding an annual general meeting of the company has expired; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: does not affect any liability already incurred by reason of default in holding an annual general meeting.

subsection.content: If an annual general meeting would be required to be held in respect of a financial year but for this section, and the meeting has not been held, any member of the company may, by notice to the company not later than 3 months before the end of the period within which the company would be required to hold an annual general meeting in respect of that financial year but for this section, require the holding of an annual general meeting in respect of that financial year.
A notice mentioned in subsection (5) must be given in hard copy form or in electronic form.
If a notice mentioned in subsection (5) is given, section 610 applies in respect of the financial year to which the notice relates.

section.name: s614
section.heading: Revocation of resolution dispensing with annual general meeting

subsection.content: A company may revoke a resolution mentioned in section 613(1) by passing an ordinary resolution to that effect.

subsection.leadIn: If a resolution mentioned in section 613(1) is revoked or otherwise ceases to have effect, the company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is required to hold an annual general meeting in accordance with section 610; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is not required to hold an annual general meeting in respect of a financial year that, but for this paragraph, would be required to be held within 3 months after the resolution ceases to have effect.

subsection.content: Subsection (2) does not affect any obligation of the company to hold an annual general meeting in respect of a financial year in accordance with a notice given under section 613(5).

section.name: s615
section.heading: Members’ power to request circulation of resolution for annual general meeting

subsection.content: If a company is required to hold an annual general meeting under section 610, the members of the company may request the company to give, to members of the company entitled to receive notice of the annual general meeting, notice of a resolution that may properly be moved and is intended to be moved at that meeting.

subsection.leadIn: A company must give notice of a resolution if it has received requests that it do so from—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the members of the company representing at least 2.5% of the total voting rights of all the members who have a right to vote on the resolution at the annual general meeting to which the requests relate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at least 50 members who have a right to vote on the resolution at the annual general meeting to which the requests relate.

subsection.leadIn: A request—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be sent to the company in hard copy form or in electronic form;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must identify the resolution of which notice is to be given;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must be authenticated by the person or persons making it; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: must be received by the company not later than—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: 6 weeks before the annual general meeting to which the requests relate; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if later, the time at which notice is given of that meeting.

section.name: s616
section.heading: Company’s duty to circulate resolution for annual general meeting

subsection.leadIn: A company that is required under section 615 to give notice of a resolution must send a copy of it at the company’s own expense to each member of the company entitled to receive notice of the annual general meeting—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the same manner as the notice of the meeting; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at the same time as, or as soon as reasonably practicable after, it gives notice of the meeting.

subsection.content: The business that may be dealt with at an annual general meeting includes a resolution of which notice is given in accordance with subsection (1).
For the purposes of subsection (2), notice is to be regarded as having been given in accordance with subsection (1) despite the accidental omission to give notice to one or more members.
If a company contravenes subsection (1), the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 5.

section.name: s617
section.heading: Written record where company has only one member

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if a company has only one member and that member takes any decision that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be taken by the company at a general meeting; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has effect as if agreed by the company at a general meeting.

subsection.content: The member must, unless the decision is taken by way of a written resolution, provide the company with a written record of that decision within 7 days after the decision is made.
A person who contravenes subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3.
A contravention of subsection (2) does not affect the validity of any decision mentioned in that subsection.

section.name: s618
section.heading: Records of resolutions and meetings, etc.

subsection.leadIn: A company must keep records comprising—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: copies of all resolutions of members passed otherwise than at general meetings;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: minutes of all proceedings of general meetings; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: all written records provided to the company in accordance with section 116BC(1) of the predecessor Ordinance or section 617(2).

subsection.content: A company must keep the copy, minutes or written record under subsection (1) for at least 10 years from the date of the resolution, meeting or decision, as the case may be.

If a company contravenes subsection (1) or (2), the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 5 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $1,000 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s619
section.heading: Place where records must be kept

subsection.leadIn: A company must keep a specified record at— (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 64)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the company’s registered office; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a prescribed place.

subsection.content: A company must notify the Registrar of the place at which a specified record is kept. The notice must be in the specified form and delivered to the Registrar for registration within 15 days after the specified record is first kept at that place. (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 64)

A company must notify the Registrar of any change (other than a change of the address of the company’s registered office) in the place at which a specified record is kept. The notice must be in the specified form and delivered to the Registrar for registration within 15 days after the change. (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 64)

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2) does not require a company to notify the Registrar of the place at which a specified record is kept, if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a specified record that came into existence on or after the commencement date# of this section—it has at all times been kept at the company’s registered office; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: for a specified record that is a copy of a resolution, minutes or written record mentioned in section 618(1) which came into existence before that commencement date#—

subparagraph.content: immediately before that commencement date#, the company kept the specified record for the purposes of section 119A of the predecessor Ordinance; and

on and after that commencement date#, the specified record is kept for the purposes of section 618 at the place at which it was kept immediately before that commencement date#. (Replaced 35 of 2018 s. 64)

subsection.content: If a company contravenes subsection (1), (2) or (3), the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 5 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $1,000 for each day during which the offence continues.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: prescribed (訂明) means prescribed by regulations made under section 657; (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 64)

specified record (指明紀錄) means—(a)the minutes recorded in accordance with section 481(1) of proceedings at a meeting of directors held on or after the commencement date* of section 64 of the Companies (Amendment) (No. 2) Ordinance 2018 (35 of 2018);(b)the resolutions passed by directors without a meeting on or after the commencement date* of section 64 of the Companies (Amendment) (No. 2) Ordinance 2018 (35 of 2018) and recorded in accordance with section 481(1);(c)the written record mentioned in section 483(1) of a decision taken by the sole director of a private company on or after the commencement date* of section 64 of the Companies (Amendment) (No. 2) Ordinance 2018 (35 of 2018); or(d)the copy of a resolution, minutes or written record mentioned in section 618(1). (Added 35 of 2018 s. 64)

section.name: s620
section.heading: Right to inspect and request copy

subsection.content: A member of a company is entitled, on request made in the prescribed manner and without charge, to inspect, in accordance with regulations made under section 657, the records kept by the company under section 618.
A member of the company is entitled, on request and on payment of a prescribed fee, to be provided with a copy of any of those records in accordance with regulations made under section 657.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: prescribed (訂明) means prescribed by regulations made under section 657.

section.name: s621
section.heading: Records as evidence of resolutions etc.

subsection.leadIn: If the record of a resolution of members passed otherwise than at a general meeting is kept under section 618(1)(a) and purports to be signed by a director of the company or company secretary of the company, then—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the record is evidence of the passing of the resolution; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: until the contrary is proved, the requirements of this Ordinance with respect to those proceedings are to be regarded as having been complied with.

subsection.content: The minutes of proceedings of a general meeting kept under section 618(1)(b), if purporting to be signed by the chairperson of that meeting or by the chairperson of the next general meeting, are evidence of the proceedings. (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 65)

subsection.leadIn: If the proceedings of a general meeting of a company are evidenced by minutes under subsection (2), then, until the contrary is proved— (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 65)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the meeting is to be regarded as having been duly held and convened;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: all proceedings at the meeting are to be regarded as having duly taken place; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: all appointments made at the meeting are to be regarded as valid.

subsection.content: If a company has only one member and that member provides the company with a written record of a decision in accordance with section 617(2), the record is sufficient evidence of the decision having been taken by the member.

section.name: s622
section.heading: Registration of and requirements relating to certain resolutions, etc.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a special resolution, other than a special resolution to change the name of a company passed under section 107 or 770;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a resolution agreed to by all the members of a company that, if not so agreed to, would not have been effective for its purpose unless passed as a special resolution;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a resolution or agreement agreed to by all the members of a class that, if not so agreed to, would not have been effective for its purpose unless passed by some particular majority or otherwise in some particular manner;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a resolution or agreement that effectively binds all the members of a class though not agreed to by all those members;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: an agreement made for the purposes of section 359(1)(b)(iii);

paragraph.name: f
g
paragraph.content: a resolution passed under section 613;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: a resolution requiring a company to be wound up voluntarily, passed under section 228(1)(a) of the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32);

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: a resolution varying any matter or provision in the articles of a company that is expressly authorized by the articles to be varied by ordinary resolution;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: an order of the Court (which alters a company’s articles) a copy of which is required to be delivered to the Registrar under section 96; and

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: an order of the Court which alters a resolution or an agreement referred to in paragraph (a), (b), (c), (d), (e), (f), (g), (h) or (i).

subsection.content: The company must deliver a copy of the order under subsection (1)(k), resolution or agreement to the Registrar for registration within 15 days after it is made or passed.

subsection.leadIn: The company must ensure that a copy of the resolution, agreement or order of the Court that is for the time being in force is included in or annexed to every copy of the articles issued, as the case may be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: after the passing of the resolution; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: after the making of the agreement or the order of the Court.

subsection.content: Subsection (3) does not apply to an existing company whose articles have not been registered under this Ordinance or any former Companies Ordinance.

If the company is an existing company whose articles have not been registered under this Ordinance or any former Companies Ordinance, the company must send a copy of the resolution, agreement or order of the Court that is for the time being in force to any member at that member’s request, without charge.

If the resolution or agreement is not in writing, a reference to a copy of the resolution or agreement in subsections (2), (3) and (5) is to be construed as a written memorandum setting out the terms of the resolution or agreement.
