paragraph.content: must state that the holder may, within 2 months after the date of the notice, indicate the holder’s choice by a letter sent to the offeror at an address specified in the notice; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must state which consideration specified in the offer will apply if the holder does not indicate a choice.

subsection.content: If the takeover offer provides that the holder of shares is to receive shares in or debentures of the offeror, with an option to receive some other consideration to be provided by a third party instead, the offeror may indicate in the notice that the terms of the takeover offer include the option.

If the offeror does not indicate in the notice that the terms of the takeover offer include the option, the offeror may offer in the notice a corresponding option to receive some other consideration to be provided by the offeror.

For the purposes of subsection (5), consideration is to be regarded as being provided by a third party if it is made available to the offeror on terms that it is to be used by the offeror as consideration for the takeover offer.

section.name: s695
section.heading: Offeror’s right to buy out minority shareholders

subsection.content: This section applies if a notice is given under section 693 to the holder of any shares.
Unless the Court makes an order under subsection (3), the offeror is entitled and bound to acquire the shares on the terms of the takeover offer.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may, on application by the holder made within 2 months after the date on which the notice was given, order that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the offeror is not entitled and bound to acquire the shares; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the offeror is entitled and bound to acquire the shares on the terms specified in the order.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the takeover offer falls within section 694(4), the terms of the takeover offer are to be regarded as including the particulars and statements included in the notice for the purposes of that section;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the takeover offer falls within section 694(5), the terms of the takeover offer are to be regarded as not including the option unless the offeror indicates otherwise in the notice; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if, within 2 months after the date of the notice, the holder of the shares, by a letter sent to the offeror at an address specified in the notice, exercises the corresponding option offered under section 694(6), the terms of the takeover offer are to be regarded as including the corresponding option.

section.name: s696
section.heading: Obligations of offeror with right to buy out minority shareholders

subsection.content: If, by virtue of section 695(2), an offeror is entitled and bound to acquire any shares in a company, the offeror must comply with subsection (3) within 2 months after the date of the notice.

If an application for the purposes of section 695(3) is pending at the end of those 2 months, the offeror must comply with subsection (3) as soon as practicable after the application has been disposed of, unless the Court orders that the offeror is not entitled and bound to acquire the shares.

subsection.leadIn: The offeror—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: must send to the company—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a copy of the notice under section 693; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an instrument of transfer of the shares to which the notice relates, executed on behalf of the holder of the shares by a person appointed by the offeror; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must pay or transfer to the company the consideration for the shares to which the notice relates.

subsection.content: Subsection (3)(a)(ii) does not require the offeror to send to the company an instrument of transfer of any shares for which a share warrant is for the time being outstanding.

section.name: s697
section.heading: Company must register offeror as shareholder
section.content: On receiving an instrument of transfer under section 696(3)(a)(ii), the company must register the offeror as the holder of the shares.

section.name: s698
section.heading: Company must hold consideration paid by offeror on trust

subsection.content: On receiving any consideration under section 696(3)(b) in respect of any shares, the company must hold the consideration on trust for the person who, before the offeror acquired the shares, was entitled to them.
If the consideration consists of any money, the company must deposit the money into a separate interest-bearing bank account.

subsection.leadIn: The company must not pay out or deliver the consideration to any person claiming to be entitled to it unless the person produces to the company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the share certificate or other evidence of title to the shares; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an indemnity to the company’s satisfaction.

section.name: s699
section.heading: Provisions supplementary to section 698

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person entitled to the consideration held on trust under section 698(1) cannot be found;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the company has made reasonable enquiries at reasonable intervals to find that person; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: 12 years have elapsed since the consideration was received, or the company is wound up.

subsection.leadIn: The company, or if the company is wound up, the liquidator, must sell—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any consideration other than cash; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any benefit other than cash that has accrued from the consideration.

subsection.leadIn: The company, or if the company is wound up, the liquidator, must pay into court a sum representing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the consideration so far as it is cash;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the proceeds of any sale under subsection (2); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any interest, dividend or other benefit that has accrued from the consideration.

subsection.content: The trust terminates on the payment being made under subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: The expenses of the following may be paid out of the consideration held on trust—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the enquiries mentioned in subsection (1)(b);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the sale mentioned in subsection (2);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the proceedings relating to the payment into court mentioned in subsection (3).

section.name: s700
section.heading: Offeror may be required to buy out minority shareholders

subsection.leadIn: If, in the case of a takeover offer that does not relate to shares of different classes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the offeror has, by virtue of acceptances of the offer, acquired, or contracted unconditionally to acquire, some but not all of the shares to which the offer relates; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at any time before the end of the offer period, the shares in the company controlled by the offeror represent at least 90% in number of the shares in the company (excluding treasury shares), (Amended 1 of 2025 s. 14)

subsection.continued: the holder of any shares to which the offer relates who has not accepted the offer before the end of that period may, by a letter addressed to the offeror, require the offeror to acquire those shares.

subsection.leadIn: If, in the case of a takeover offer that relates to shares of different classes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the offeror has, by virtue of acceptances of the offer, acquired, or contracted unconditionally to acquire, some but not all of the shares of any class to which the offer relates; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at any time before the end of the offer period, the shares of that class controlled by the offeror represent at least 90% in number of the shares of that class (excluding treasury shares), (Amended 35 of 2018 s. 71; 1 of 2025 s. 14)

subsection.continued: the holder of any shares of that class to which the offer relates who has not accepted the offer before the end of that period may, by a letter addressed to the offeror, require the offeror to acquire those shares.

subsection.leadIn: Rights given to the holder of any shares by this section to require an offeror to acquire the shares are only exercisable within 3 months after whichever is the later of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the end of the offer period;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date of the notice given to the holder under section 701.

subsection.content: If the takeover offer gives the holder of shares a choice of consideration, that holder may indicate the holder’s choice in the letter requiring the offeror to acquire the shares.

subsection.leadIn: In this section, a reference to shares controlled by an offeror is a reference to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shares that are held by the offeror, by an associate of the offeror or by a nominee on the offeror’s behalf;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shares that the offeror has, by virtue of acceptances of the takeover offer, acquired or contracted unconditionally to acquire; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: other shares that the offeror, an associate of the offeror, or a nominee on the offeror’s behalf, has acquired, or has contracted, unconditionally or subject to conditions being satisfied, to acquire.

section.name: s701
section.heading: Offeror must notify minority shareholders of right to be bought out

subsection.leadIn: If the holder of any shares is entitled under section 700 to require an offeror to acquire the shares, the offeror must give notice to the holder of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the holder’s rights under that section; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the period within which those rights are exercisable.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) does not apply if the offeror has given the holder a notice under section 693 that the offeror desires to acquire the shares.
An offeror who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 5.

section.name: s702
section.heading: Notice to minority shareholders

subsection.leadIn: A notice to a holder of shares under section 701—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be given in the specified form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be given to the holder within one month after the first day on which the holder of the shares is entitled under section 700 to require the offeror to acquire those shares.

subsection.content: If the notice is given before the end of the offer period of the takeover offer, it must state that the offer is still open for acceptance.

subsection.leadIn: The notice must be given to the holder of shares—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by delivering it personally to that holder in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: by sending it by registered post to that holder to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an address of that holder in Hong Kong registered in the books of the company; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if there is no such address, an address in Hong Kong supplied by that holder to the company for the giving of notice to that holder; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the manner directed by the Registrar on an application made under subsection (4).

subsection.leadIn: An offeror may apply to the Registrar for directions regarding the manner in which the notice is to be given to a holder of shares if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is no address of the holder in Hong Kong registered in the books of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the holder has not supplied to the company an address in Hong Kong for the giving of notice to the holder.

subsection.leadIn: If the takeover offer gives the holder of shares a choice of consideration, the notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must give particulars of the choices;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must state that the holder may indicate the holder’s choice in the letter requiring the offeror to acquire any shares under section 700; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must state which consideration specified in the offer will apply if the holder does not indicate a choice.

subsection.content: If subsection (1), (2), (3) or (5) is contravened, the offeror commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 4.

If the takeover offer provides that the holder of shares is to receive shares in or debentures of the offeror, with an option to receive some other considerations to be provided by a third party instead, the offeror may indicate in the notice that the terms of the takeover offer include the option.

If the offeror does not indicate in the notice that the terms of the takeover offer include the option, the offeror may offer in the notice a corresponding option to receive some other consideration to be provided by the offeror.

For the purposes of subsection (7), consideration is to be regarded as being provided by a third party if it is made available to the offeror on terms that it is to be used by the offeror as consideration for the takeover offer.

section.name: s703
section.heading: Minority shareholders’ right to be bought out by offeror

subsection.content: This section applies if the holder of any shares requires the offeror to acquire the shares under section 700.

Unless the Court makes an order under subsection (3), the offeror is entitled and bound to acquire the shares on the terms of the takeover offer or on other terms as agreed between that holder and the offeror.
The Court may, on application by the holder or offeror, order that the offeror is entitled and bound to acquire the shares on the terms specified in the order.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the takeover offer falls within section 702(5), the terms of the takeover offer are to be regarded as including the particulars and statements included in the notice for the purposes of that section;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the takeover offer falls within section 702(7), the terms of the takeover offer are to be regarded as not including the option unless the offeror indicates otherwise in the notice under section 701; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if, when requiring the offeror to acquire the shares, the holder of the shares exercises the corresponding option offered under section 702(8), the terms of the takeover offer are to be regarded as including the corresponding option.

section.name: s704
section.heading: Shareholder to be regarded as not having exercised right to be bought out in certain circumstances

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the holder of any shares exercises rights given by section 700 to require an offeror to acquire the shares;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: at the time when those rights are exercised, there are shares in the company—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that the offeror has contracted to acquire subject to conditions being satisfied; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in relation to which the contract has not become unconditional; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the requirement imposed by section 700(1)(b) or (2)(b) (as the case may be) would not be satisfied if those shares were not taken into account.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of section 703, the holder of shares is to be regarded as not having exercised the rights to require the offeror to acquire the shares unless, at any time before the end of the period during which those rights are exercisable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a takeover offer that does not relate to shares of different classes, the shares that the offeror has, by virtue of acceptances of the offer, acquired or contracted unconditionally to acquire, with or without any other shares in the company that the offeror has acquired, or has contracted unconditionally to acquire, represent at least 90% in number of the shares in the company (excluding treasury shares); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a takeover offer that relates to shares of different classes, the shares of any class that the offeror has, by virtue of acceptances of the offer, acquired or contracted unconditionally to acquire, with or without any other shares of that class that the offeror has acquired, or has contracted unconditionally to acquire, represent at least 90% in number of the shares of that class (excluding treasury shares). (Amended 1 of 2025 s. 15)

division.name: D5
division.heading: Compulsory Acquisition after General Offer for Share Buy-back

section.name: s705
section.heading: Interpretation

subsection.leadIn: In this Division—
subsection.def: non-tendering member (不售股成員), in relation to a general offer, means a member who gives notice under section 711(1) that the member will not tender any shares to be bought back by the repurchasing company under the offer.

subsection.leadIn: In this Division, a reference to shares that are held by a non-tendering member includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shares that are held by an associate of the non-tendering member or by a nominee on the non-tendering member’s behalf; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shares that the non-tendering member, an associate of the non-tendering member, or a nominee on the non-tendering member’s behalf, has contracted, unconditionally or subject to conditions being satisfied, to acquire.

section.name: s706
section.heading: Application of Division to convertible securities and debentures

subsection.content: This Division applies in relation to debentures of a repurchasing company that are convertible into shares in the company, or to securities of a repurchasing company that are convertible into, or entitle the holder to subscribe for, shares in the company, as if those debentures or securities were shares of a separate class of the company. A reference to a holder of shares, and to shares being allotted, is to be read accordingly.

subsection.leadIn: In this Division, a reference to 90% in number of the shares of any class is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of securities mentioned in subsection (1), a reference to 90% of the number of those securities; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of debentures mentioned in subsection (1), a reference to 90% of the total amount payable on those debentures.

section.name: s707
section.heading: General offer

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Division, a listed company’s offer to buy back shares in the company is a general offer if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: it is an offer to buy back all the shares, or all the shares of any class, in the company, except—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: those that, at the date of the offer, are held by the repurchasing company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the terms of the offer are the same—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: where the offer does not relate to shares of different classes, in relation to all the shares to which the offer relates; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: where the offer relates to shares of different classes, in relation to all the shares of each class to which the offer relates.

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (1)—
subsection.def: shares (股份) means shares, other than specified treasury shares, that have been allotted on the date of the offer. (Amended 1 of 2025 s. 16)

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (1)(a)(ii), a reference to shares that are held by the repurchasing company—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.leadIn: excludes shares that are the subject of a contract—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: entered into by the repurchasing company with a holder of shares in that company in order to secure that the holder will accept the offer when it is made; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: entered into for no consideration and by deed, for consideration of negligible value, or for consideration consisting of a promise by the repurchasing company to make the offer.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)(b), even though, in relation to all the shares, or all the shares of a class of shares, to which an offer relates, there is a difference in the value of consideration offered for the shares allotted earlier as against the value of consideration offered for those allotted later, the terms of the offer are to be regarded as the same in relation to all the shares concerned if—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the difference in value of consideration merely reflects that difference in entitlement to dividend; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: but for the difference in the value of consideration, the terms of the offer would be the same in relation to all the shares concerned.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)(b), even though, in relation to all the shares, or all the shares of a class of shares, to which an offer relates, there is a difference in the form of consideration offered, the terms of the offer are to be regarded as the same in relation to all the shares concerned if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the law of a place outside Hong Kong precludes an offer of consideration in the form specified in the terms of the offer, or precludes it except after compliance by the repurchasing company with conditions with which the repurchasing company is unable to comply or that the repurchasing company regards as unduly onerous;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: consideration in another form is offered to a person to whom an offer of consideration in the specified form is so precluded;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person is able to receive consideration in that other form that is of substantially equivalent value; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: but for the difference in the form of consideration, the terms of the offer would be the same in relation to all the shares concerned.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (1), a general offer may include, among the shares to which it relates— (Amended 1 of 2025 s. 16)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shares that will be allotted after the date of the offer but before a date specified in the offer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: all or any specified treasury shares that are sold or transferred under section 272D(b) before a date specified in the offer. (Amended 1 of 2025 s. 16)

subsection.leadIn: In subsections (2) and (6)—

def.name: SpecifiedTreasuryShares
def.leadIn: specified treasury shares (指明庫存股份) means shares—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that are treasury shares held by the repurchasing company on the date of the offer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that become treasury shares held by the repurchasing company after the date of the offer but before a date specified in the offer. (Added 1 of 2025 s. 16)

section.name: s708
section.heading: Non-communication etc. does not prevent offer from being general offer

subsection.leadIn: Even though an offer to buy back shares is not communicated to a holder of shares, that does not prevent the offer from being a general offer for the purposes of this Division if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: no Hong Kong address for the holder is registered in the repurchasing company’s register of members;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the offer was not communicated to the holder in order not to contravene the law of a place outside Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: either—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the offer is published in the Gazette; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the offer can be inspected, or a copy of it obtained, at a place in Hong Kong or on a website, and a notice is published in the Gazette specifying the address of that place or website.

subsection.content: It is not to be inferred from subsection (1) that an offer that is not communicated to a holder of shares cannot be a general offer for the purposes of this Division unless the conditions specified in paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of that subsection are satisfied.

Even though it is impossible or more difficult for a person, by reason of the law of a place outside Hong Kong, to accept an offer to buy back shares, that does not prevent the offer from being a general offer for the purposes of this Division.

It is not to be inferred from subsection (3) that an offer that is impossible, or more difficult, for certain persons to accept cannot be a general offer for the purposes of this Division unless the reason for the impossibility or difficulty is the one mentioned in that subsection.

section.name: s709
section.heading: Shares to which general offer relates

subsection.content: For the purposes of this Division, if, after a general offer is made but before the end of the offer period, the repurchasing company buys back, or contracts unconditionally to buy back, any of the shares to which the offer relates but does not do so by virtue of acceptances of the offer, those shares are not to be regarded as shares to which the offer relates. This subsection has effect subject to subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Division, those shares are to be regarded as shares to which the general offer relates, and the repurchasing company is to be regarded as having bought them back or contracted to buy them back by virtue of acceptances of that offer, if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the value of the consideration for which the shares are bought back, or contracted to be bought back, at the time of the buy-back or contract, does not exceed the value of the consideration specified in the terms of that offer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: those terms are subsequently revised so that when the revision is announced, the value of the consideration for which the shares are bought back, or contracted to be bought back, at the time of the buy-back or contract, no longer exceeds the value of the consideration specified in those terms.

subsection.content: For the purposes of this Division, shares that an associate of the repurchasing company, or a nominee on the repurchasing company’s behalf, holds, or has contracted, unconditionally or subject to conditions being satisfied, to buy back, whether at the date of the general offer or subsequently, are not to be regarded as shares to which that offer relates, even if that offer extends to those shares. This subsection has effect subject to subsection (4).

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Division, where, after a general offer is made but before the end of the offer period, an associate of the repurchasing company, or a nominee on the repurchasing company’s behalf, buys back, or contracts unconditionally to buy back, any of the shares to which the offer relates, the shares are to be regarded as shares to which the offer relates if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the value of the consideration for which the shares are bought back, or contracted to be bought back, at the time of the buy-back or contract, does not exceed the value of the consideration specified in the terms of the offer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: those terms are subsequently revised so that when the revision is announced, the value of the consideration for which the shares are bought back, or contracted to be bought back, at the time of the buy-back or contract, no longer exceeds the value of the consideration specified in those terms.

subsection.content: For the purposes of this Division, the shares held by a non-tendering member are not to be regarded as shares to which the general offer relates, even if that offer extends to those shares.

section.name: s710
section.heading: Revised offer not to be regarded as fresh offer
section.leadIn: For the purposes of this Division, a revision of the terms of an offer to buy back shares is not to be regarded as the making of a fresh offer if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the terms of the offer make provision for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: their revision; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: acceptances on the previous terms to be treated as acceptances on the revised terms; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the revision is made in accordance with that provision.

section.name: s711
section.heading: Member may give notice that member will not tender shares for buy-back under general offer

subsection.content: A member of a repurchasing company may, on or before the date on which notice of an authorizing meeting of the company is given, give notice to every other member of the company that the member will not tender any shares held by the member to be bought back by the company under the general offer.
A non-tendering member is not entitled to tender any shares held by the member to be bought back by the repurchasing company under the general offer even if that offer extends to those shares.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: authorizing meeting (授權會議), in relation to a repurchasing company, means a meeting of the company called for the purpose of authorizing a general offer that the company intends to make.

section.name: s712
section.heading: Repurchasing company may give notice to buy out minority shareholders

subsection.content: This section applies if a member or members of the repurchasing company has or have given notice under section 711 that the member or members will not tender any shares to be bought back by that company under a general offer.

If, in the case of a general offer that does not relate to shares of different classes, the repurchasing company has, by virtue of acceptances of the offer, bought back, or contracted unconditionally to buy back, at least 90% in number of the shares to which the offer relates, the repurchasing company may give notice to the holder of any other shares to which the offer relates that it desires to buy back those shares.

If, in the case of a general offer that relates to shares of different classes, the repurchasing company has, by virtue of acceptances of the offer, bought back, or contracted unconditionally to buy back, at least 90% in number of the shares of any class to which the offer relates, the repurchasing company may give notice to the holder of any other shares of that class to which the offer relates that it desires to buy back those shares.

If, in the case of a general offer that does not relate to shares of different classes, the repurchasing company has, by virtue of acceptances of the offer, bought back, or contracted unconditionally to buy back, less than 90% in number of the shares to which the offer relates, the repurchasing company may apply to the Court for an order authorizing it to give notice to the holder of any other shares to which the offer relates that it desires to buy back those shares.

If, in the case of a general offer that relates to shares of different classes, the repurchasing company has, by virtue of acceptances of the offer, bought back, or contracted unconditionally to buy back, less than 90% in number of the shares of any class to which the offer relates, the repurchasing company may apply to the Court for an order authorizing it to give notice to the holder of any other shares of that class to which the offer relates that it desires to buy back those shares.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may, on application under subsection (4) or (5), make the order if it is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: after reasonable enquiry, the repurchasing company has been unable to trace one or more of the persons holding shares to which the general offer relates;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: had the person, or all those persons, accepted the general offer, the repurchasing company would have, by virtue of acceptances of that offer, bought back, or contracted unconditionally to buy back, at least 90% in number of the shares, or the shares of any class, to which that offer relates; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the consideration offered is fair and reasonable.

subsection.content: The Court must not make the order unless it is satisfied that it is just and equitable to do so having regard to all the circumstances and, in particular, to the number of holders of shares who have been traced but who have not accepted the general offer.
If the Court makes an order authorizing the repurchasing company to give notice to the holder of any shares, the repurchasing company may give notice to that holder.

section.name: s713
section.heading: Notice to minority shareholders

subsection.leadIn: A notice to a holder of shares under section 712—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be given in the specified form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: must be given to the holder before whichever is the earlier of the following—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the end of the period of 3 months beginning on the day after the end of the offer period of the general offer;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the end of the period of 6 months beginning on the date of the general offer.

subsection.leadIn: The notice must be given to the holder of shares—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by delivering it personally to that holder in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: by sending it by registered post to that holder to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an address of that holder in Hong Kong registered in the books of the company; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if there is no such address, an address in Hong Kong supplied by that holder to the company for the giving of notice to that holder; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the manner directed by the Registrar on an application made under subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: The repurchasing company may apply to the Registrar for directions regarding the manner in which the notice is to be given to a holder of shares if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is no address of the holder in Hong Kong registered in the books of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the holder has not supplied to the company an address in Hong Kong for the giving of notice to the holder.

subsection.leadIn: If the general offer gives the holder of shares a choice of consideration, the notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must give particulars of the choices;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must state that the holder may, within 2 months after the date of the notice, indicate the holder’s choice by a letter sent to the repurchasing company at an address specified in the notice; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must state which consideration specified in the offer will apply if the holder does not indicate a choice.

section.name: s714
section.heading: Repurchasing company’s right to buy out minority shareholders

subsection.content: This section applies if a notice is given under section 712 to the holder of any shares.
Unless the Court makes an order under subsection (3), the repurchasing company is entitled and bound to buy back the shares on the terms of the general offer.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may, on application by the holder made within 2 months after the date on which the notice was given, order that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the repurchasing company is not entitled and bound to buy back the shares; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the repurchasing company is entitled and bound to buy back the shares on the terms specified in the order.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (2), if the general offer falls within section 713(4), the terms of the general offer are to be regarded as including the particulars and statements included in the notice for the purposes of that section.

section.name: s715
section.heading: Obligations of repurchasing company with right to buy out minority shareholders

subsection.content: If, by virtue of section 714(2), a repurchasing company is entitled and bound to buy back any shares in the company, the company must comply with section 716 within 2 months after the date of the notice.

If an application for the purposes of section 714(3) is pending at the end of those 2 months, the repurchasing company must comply with section 716 as soon as practicable after the application has been disposed of.

section.name: s716
section.heading: Repurchasing company must pay for shares to which notice relates

subsection.leadIn: The repurchasing company must pay the consideration for any shares to which the notice under section 712 relates to the holder of the shares if that holder produces to the repurchasing company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the share certificate or other evidence of title to the shares; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an indemnity to the repurchasing company’s satisfaction.

subsection.content: The repurchasing company must cancel any other shares to which the notice under section 712 relates and deposit the consideration for those shares into a separate interest-bearing bank account.
The repurchasing company must hold any consideration deposited into a bank account under subsection (2) on trust for the person who, before the company bought back the shares, was entitled to them.

subsection.leadIn: The repurchasing company must not pay out or deliver the consideration to any person claiming to be entitled to it unless the person produces to the repurchasing company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the share certificate or other evidence of title to the shares; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an indemnity to the repurchasing company’s satisfaction.

section.name: s717
section.heading: Provisions supplementary to section 716

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person entitled to the consideration held on trust under section 716(3) cannot be found;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the repurchasing company has made reasonable enquiries at reasonable intervals to find that person; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: 12 years have elapsed since the consideration was received, or the repurchasing company is wound up.

subsection.leadIn: The repurchasing company, or if the repurchasing company is wound up, the liquidator or provisional liquidator, must sell—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any consideration other than cash; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any benefit other than cash that has accrued from the consideration.

subsection.leadIn: The repurchasing company, or if the repurchasing company is wound up, the liquidator or provisional liquidator, must pay into court a sum representing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the consideration so far as it is cash;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the proceeds of any sale under subsection (2); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any interest, dividend or other benefit that has accrued from the consideration.

subsection.content: The trust terminates on the payment being made under subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: The expenses of the following may be paid out of the consideration held on trust—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the enquiries mentioned in subsection (1)(b);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the sale mentioned in subsection (2);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the proceedings relating to the payment into court mentioned in subsection (3).

section.name: s718
section.heading: Repurchasing company may be required to buy out minority

subsection.content: This section applies if a member or members of the repurchasing company has or have given notice under section 711 that the member or members will not tender any shares to be bought back by that company under a general offer.

subsection.leadIn: If, in the case of a general offer that does not relate to shares of different classes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the repurchasing company has, by virtue of acceptances of the offer, bought back, or contracted unconditionally to buy back, some but not all of the shares to which the offer relates; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at any time before the end of the offer period, the shares in the repurchasing company controlled by that company, with or without the shares in the repurchasing company held by the non-tendering member, represent at least 90% in number of the shares in the repurchasing company (excluding treasury shares), (Amended 1 of 2025 s. 17)

subsection.continued: the holder of any shares to which the offer relates who has not accepted the offer before the end of that period may, by a letter addressed to the repurchasing company, require that company to buy back those shares.

subsection.leadIn: If, in the case of a general offer that relates to shares of different classes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the repurchasing company has, by virtue of acceptances of the offer, bought back, or contracted unconditionally to buy back, some but not all of the shares of any class to which the offer relates; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at any time before the end of the offer period, the shares of that class controlled by the repurchasing company, with or without the shares of that class held by the non-tendering member, represent at least 90% in number of the shares of that class (excluding treasury shares), (Amended 1 of 2025 s. 17)

subsection.continued: the holder of any shares of that class to which the offer relates who has not accepted the offer before the end of that period may, by a letter addressed to the repurchasing company, require that company to buy back those shares.

subsection.leadIn: Rights given to the holder of any shares by this section to require a repurchasing company to buy back the shares are only exercisable within 3 months after whichever is the later of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the end of the offer period;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date of the notice given to the holder under section 719.

subsection.content: If the general offer gives the holder of shares a choice of consideration, that holder may indicate the holder’s choice in the letter requiring the repurchasing company to buy back the shares.

subsection.leadIn: In this section, a reference to shares controlled by a repurchasing company is a reference to any of the following shares (excluding treasury shares)— (Amended 1 of 2025 s. 17)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shares that are held by an associate of the repurchasing company or by a nominee on the repurchasing company’s behalf;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shares that the repurchasing company has, by virtue of acceptances of the general offer, acquired or contracted unconditionally to acquire; (Amended 1 of 2025 s. 17)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: other shares that the repurchasing company, an associate of the repurchasing company, or a nominee on the repurchasing company’s behalf, has acquired, or has contracted, unconditionally or subject to conditions being satisfied, to acquire.

section.name: s719
section.heading: Repurchasing company must notify minority shareholders of right to be bought out

subsection.leadIn: If the holder of any shares is entitled under section 718 to require a repurchasing company to buy back the shares, the repurchasing company must give notice to the holder of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the holder’s rights under that section; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the period within which those rights are exercisable.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) does not apply if the repurchasing company has given the holder a notice under section 712 that it desires to buy back the shares.
A repurchasing company that contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 5.

section.name: s720
section.heading: Notice to minority shareholders

subsection.leadIn: A notice to a holder of shares under section 719—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be given in the specified form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be given to the holder within one month after the first day on which the holder of the shares is entitled under section 718 to require the repurchasing company to buy back those shares.

subsection.content: If the notice is given before the end of the offer period of the general offer, it must state that the offer is still open for acceptance.

subsection.leadIn: The notice must be given to the holder of shares—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by delivering it personally to that holder in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: by sending it by registered post to that holder to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an address of that holder in Hong Kong registered in the books of the company; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if there is no such address, an address in Hong Kong supplied by that holder to the company for the giving of notice to that holder; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the manner directed by the Registrar on an application made under subsection (4).

subsection.leadIn: A repurchasing company may apply to the Registrar for directions regarding the manner in which the notice is to be given to a holder of shares if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is no address of the holder in Hong Kong registered in the books of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the holder has not supplied to the company an address in Hong Kong for the giving of notice to the holder.

subsection.leadIn: If the general offer gives the holder of shares a choice of consideration, the notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must give particulars of the choices;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must state that the holder may indicate the holder’s choice in the letter requiring the repurchasing company to buy back any shares under section 718; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must state which consideration specified in the offer will apply if the holder does not indicate a choice.

subsection.content: If subsection (1), (2), (3) or (5) is contravened, the repurchasing company commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 4.

section.name: s721
section.heading: Minority shareholders’ right to be bought out by repurchasing company

subsection.content: This section applies if the holder of any shares requires the repurchasing company to buy back the shares under section 718.

Unless the Court makes an order under subsection (3), the repurchasing company is entitled and bound to buy back the shares on the terms of the general offer or on other terms as agreed between that holder and the repurchasing company.
The Court may, on application by the holder or repurchasing company, order that the repurchasing company is entitled and bound to buy back the shares on the terms specified in the order.

For the purposes of subsection (2), if the general offer falls within section 720(5), the terms of the general offer are to be regarded as including the particulars and statements included in the notice for the purposes of that section.

part.name: P14
part.heading: Remedies for Protection of Companies’ or Members’ Interests

section.name: s722
section.heading: Interpretation

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: company (公司) includes a non-Hong Kong company.

subsection.content: In this Part, a reference to a company’s articles, in the case of a company not having articles, is to be read as the instrument constituting or defining the constitution of the company.

division.name: D2
division.heading: Remedies for Unfair Prejudice to Members’ Interests

section.name: s723
section.heading: Interpretation

subsection.leadIn: In this Division, a reference to a member of a company includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the personal representative of a person who, immediately before the person’s death, was a member of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a trustee of, or a person beneficially interested in, the shares of the company by virtue of the will or intestacy of another person who, immediately before that other person’s death, was a member of the company.

subsection.content: In this Division, a reference to a past member of a company includes the personal representative of a person who, immediately before the person’s death, was a past member of the company.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Division, a person is not a past member of a company unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person was, but is no longer, a member of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person ceased to be such a member on or after 15 July 2005.

section.name: s724
section.heading: When Court may order remedies

subsection.leadIn: The Court may exercise the power under section 725(1)(a) and (2) if, on a petition by a member of a company, it considers that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the company’s affairs are being or have been conducted in a manner unfairly prejudicial to the interests of the members generally or of one or more members (including the member); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an actual or proposed act or omission of the company (including one done or made on behalf of the company) is or would be so prejudicial.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may exercise the power under section 725(1)(b) and (2) if, on a petition by the Financial Secretary under section 879(3), it considers that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a company’s affairs are being or have been conducted in a manner unfairly prejudicial to the interests of the members generally or of one or more members; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an actual or proposed act or omission of a company (including one done or made on behalf of the company) is or would be so prejudicial.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may exercise the power under section 725(4) if, on a petition by a past member of a company, it considers that at the time when the past member was a member of the company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the company’s affairs were conducted in a manner unfairly prejudicial to the interests of the members at that time generally or of one or more members at that time (including the past member); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an actual act or omission of the company (including one done or made on behalf of the company) was so prejudicial.

section.name: s725
section.heading: Remedies that Court may order

subsection.leadIn: The Court may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the purposes of section 724(1), make any order that it thinks fit for giving relief in respect of the matter mentioned in section 724(1)(a) or (b); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purposes of section 724(2), make any order that it thinks fit for giving relief in respect of the matter mentioned in section 724(2)(a) or (b).

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: may make any or all of the following orders—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: an order—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: restraining the continuance of the conduct of the company’s affairs in the manner mentioned in section 724(1)(a) or (2)(a);

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: restraining the doing of the act mentioned in section 724(1)(b) or (2)(b); or

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: requiring the doing of an act that, as mentioned in section 724(1)(b) or (2)(b), the company has omitted, or has proposed to omit, to do;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an order that proceedings that the Court thinks fit be brought in the company’s name against any person, and on any terms, that the Court so orders;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.leadIn: an order appointing a receiver or manager of either or both of the following—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the company’s property, or any part of the property;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: the company’s business, or any part of the business;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.leadIn: any other order that the Court thinks fit, whether—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: for regulating the conduct of the company’s affairs in future;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: for the purchase of the shares of any member of the company by another member of the company;

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: for the purchase of the shares of any member of the company by the company and the reduction accordingly of the company’s capital; or

subparagraph.name: D
subparagraph.content: for any other purpose; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may order the company or any other person to pay any damages, and any interest on those damages, that the Court thinks fit to a member of the company whose interests have been unfairly prejudiced by the conduct of the company’s affairs or by the act or omission.

subsection.content: The Court may, on making an order under subsection (2)(a)(iii), specify the powers and duties of, and fix the remuneration of, the receiver or manager.

For the purposes of section 724(3), the Court may order the company or any other person to pay any damages, and any interest on those damages, that the Court thinks fit to a member of the company at the material time whose interests were unfairly prejudiced by the conduct of the company’s affairs or by the act or omission.

To avoid doubt, a member, past or present, of a company is not entitled to recover, by way of damages under subsection (2)(b) or (4), any loss that solely reflects the loss suffered by the company that only the company is entitled to recover under the common law.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: material time (關鍵時間) means the time when the past member was a member of the company.

section.name: s726
section.heading: Alteration of articles by order of Court

subsection.content: This section applies if a company’s articles are altered by an order under section 725.
The alteration has the same effect, and this Ordinance applies to the articles, as if the alteration were made by a resolution of the company.
Despite anything in this Ordinance, the company has no power, without the leave of the Court, to alter the articles in a way that is inconsistent with the order.
Within 15 days after the order is made, the company must deliver an office copy of the order to the Registrar for registration.

If a company contravenes subsection (4), the company, and every responsible person of the company, commit an offence, and each is liable to a fine at level 3 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $300 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s727
section.heading: Chief Justice may make rules

subsection.leadIn: Subject to the approval of the Legislative Council, the Chief Justice may make rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for regulating proceedings under this Division; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for prescribing fees payable in respect of such proceedings.

subsection.content: If the rules empower a person to put a question to another person, they may also provide that that other person’s reply to the question may be used in evidence against that other person.

subsection.leadIn: The rules may empower the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to fix any fee payable in respect of such proceedings that is not prescribed by the rules; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to vary the fee so fixed.

subsection.content: The rules may provide that a fee payable to a person in respect of such proceedings is recoverable as a debt due to the person.
A fee may be prescribed by the rules, or fixed or varied by the Court under the rules, by reference to a scale of fees and percentages.
A fee may be so prescribed, fixed or varied without reference to the amount of administrative or other costs incurred or likely to be incurred in relation to such proceedings.
A fee so prescribed, fixed or varied is not invalid by reason only of the amount of the fee.

division.name: D3
division.heading: Remedies for Others’ Conduct in relation to Companies etc.

section.name: s728
section.heading: Application of section 729

subsection.leadIn: Section 729 applies if, in relation to a company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a person has engaged, is engaging or is proposing to engage in conduct that constituted, constitutes or would constitute—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a contravention of this Ordinance;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a default relating to a contravention of this Ordinance; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: a breach specified in subsection (4); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person has refused or failed, is refusing or failing, or is proposing to refuse or fail, to do an act or thing that the person is required by this Ordinance to do.

subsection.leadIn: Section 729 also applies if, in relation to a company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a person had engaged, was engaging or was proposing to engage, before the commencement date# of this section, in—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: conduct that constituted or would constitute a default relating to a contravention of the predecessor Ordinance and that would also constitute the same default relating to a contravention of this Ordinance; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: conduct that constituted or would constitute a breach specified in subsection (4); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the engagement or proposal still subsists.

subsection.leadIn: Section 729 also applies if, in relation to a company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person had refused or failed, was refusing or failing, or was proposing to refuse or fail, before the commencement date# of this section, to do an act or thing that the person was required by the predecessor Ordinance to do;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person is also required by this Ordinance to do the act or thing; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the refusal, failure or proposal still subsists.

subsection.leadIn: The breach specified for the purposes of subsection (1)(a)(iii) or (2)(a)(iii) is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a breach of the person’s fiduciary duties owed to the company in any capacity other than as a director of the company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a breach of the person’s fiduciary or other duties as a director of the company owed to the company; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a breach of the company’s articles.

subsection.leadIn: In this section, a reference to a default relating to a contravention of this Ordinance or the predecessor Ordinance is a reference to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an attempt to contravene the Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring another person to contravene the Ordinance;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: inducing or attempting to induce, whether by threats, promises or otherwise, another person to contravene the Ordinance;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: being in any way, directly or indirectly, knowingly concerned in, or a party to, a contravention of the Ordinance by another person; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: conspiring with others to contravene the Ordinance.

section.name: s729
section.heading: Court may order remedies

subsection.leadIn: The Court may, on application by a member or creditor of the company whose interests have been, are or would be affected by the conduct or by the refusal or failure, do any or all of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: grant an injunction, on the terms that the Court thinks fit—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the case of section 728(1)(a) or (2), restraining the person from engaging in the conduct or requiring the person to do any act or thing; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of section 728(1)(b) or (3), requiring the person to do any act or thing;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: order the person to pay damages to any other person;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: declare any contract to be void or voidable to the extent specified in the order.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may, on application by the Financial Secretary under section 879(4) or (5), do any or all of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: grant an injunction, on the terms that the Court thinks fit—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the case of section 728(1)(a) or (2), restraining the person from engaging in the conduct or requiring the person to do any act or thing; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of section 728(1)(b) or (3), requiring the person to do any act or thing;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: order the person to pay damages to any other person;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: declare any contract to be void or voidable to the extent specified in the order.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may grant an injunction under subsection (1)(a)(i) or (2)(a)(i) restraining a person from engaging in a conduct—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether or not it appears to the Court that the person intends to engage again, or to continue to engage, in the conduct;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether or not the person has previously engaged in the conduct; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: whether or not there is an imminent danger of substantial damage to any other person if the person engages in the conduct.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may grant an injunction under subsection (1)(a) or (2)(a) requiring a person to do an act or thing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether or not it appears to the Court that the person intends to refuse or fail again, or to continue to refuse or fail, to do the act or thing;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether or not the person has previously refused or failed to do the act or thing; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: whether or not there is an imminent danger of substantial damage to any other person if the person refuses or fails to do the act or thing.

subsection.content: To avoid doubt, a person is not entitled to recover, by way of damages under subsection (1)(b) or (2)(b), any loss that solely reflects the loss suffered by the company that only the company is entitled to recover under the common law.

section.name: s730
section.heading: Provisions supplementary to section 729

subsection.content: The Court may grant an interim injunction or interim damages, or both, on the terms and conditions that it thinks fit pending the determination of an application under section 729(1) or (2).
The Court may discharge or vary an injunction granted under subsection (1) or section 729(1) or (2).

division.name: D4
division.heading: Derivative Action for Remedies for Misconduct against Companies etc.

section.name: s731
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: misconduct (不當行為) means fraud, negligence, breach of duty, or default in compliance with any Ordinance or rule of law;
proceedings (法律程序) means any proceedings (other than criminal proceedings) within the jurisdiction of any court.

section.name: s732
section.heading: Member of company or of associated company may bring or intervene in proceedings

subsection.content: If misconduct is committed against a company, a member of the company or of an associated company of the company may, with the leave of the Court granted under section 733, bring proceedings in respect of the misconduct before the court on behalf of the company.

If, because of misconduct committed against the company, a company fails to bring proceedings in respect of any matter, a member of the company or of an associated company of the company may, with the leave of the Court granted under section 733, bring proceedings in respect of the matter before the court on behalf of the company.

If, because of misconduct committed against the company, a company fails to diligently continue, discontinue or defend proceedings, a member of the company or of an associated company of the company may, with the leave of the Court granted under section 733, intervene in the proceedings before the court for the purpose of continuing, discontinuing or defending those proceedings on behalf of the company.

The cause of action in relation to the proceedings under subsection (1) or (2) is vested in the company. Any of those proceedings must be brought in the name of, and the relief (if any) must be sought on behalf of, the company.
The right to continue, discontinue or defend any proceedings intervened in under subsection (3) is vested in, and the relief (if any) must be sought on behalf of, the company.

Subject to section 736, this Division does not affect any common law right of a member of a company, or a member of an associated company of a company, to bring proceedings on behalf of the company, or intervene in any proceedings to which the company is a party.

This section does not prevent a member of a company, or of an associated company of a company, from bringing proceedings in respect of the company, or intervening in any proceedings to which the company is a party, on the member’s own behalf in respect of any personal right.

section.name: s733
section.heading: Leave of Court to bring or intervene in proceedings

subsection.leadIn: On application by a member of a company or of an associated company of a company, the Court may grant leave for the purposes of section 732(1), (2) or (3) if it is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the face of the application, it appears to be in the company’s interests that leave be granted to the member;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an application for leave to bring proceedings under section 732(1) or (2), there is a serious question to be tried and the company has not itself brought the proceedings; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an application for leave to intervene in proceedings under section 732(3), the company has not diligently continued, discontinued or defended the proceedings; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: except where leave is granted by the Court under subsection (5), the member has served a written notice on the company in accordance with subsection (3), and the notice complies with subsection (4).

subsection.leadIn: The Court may refuse to grant leave if it is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of an application for leave to bring proceedings under section 732(1) or (2), the member has, in the exercise of any common law right, brought proceedings on behalf of the company in respect of the same cause or matter; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of an application for leave to intervene in proceedings under section 732(3), the member has, in the exercise of any common law right, intervened in the proceedings in question to which the company is a party.

subsection.leadIn: The written notice must be served on the company, at least 14 days before the member applies for leave in respect of the company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a company as defined by section 2(1), by leaving the notice at, or by sending the notice by post to, its registered office; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a non-Hong Kong company, in a manner that the notice is sufficiently served on the company by virtue of section 803.

subsection.leadIn: The written notice must state—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the member’s intention to apply for leave for the purposes of section 732(1), (2) or (3) in respect of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the reasons for that intention.

subsection.content: The Court may grant leave to dispense with the service of a written notice for the purposes of subsection (1)(c).

section.name: s734
section.heading: Approval or ratification of conduct does not bar derivative action

subsection.leadIn: If a company’s members approve or ratify any conduct, the approval or ratification—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: does not prevent a member of the company, or of an associated company of the company, from—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: bringing proceedings under section 732(1) or (2);

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: intervening in proceedings under section 732(3); or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: applying for leave for the purposes of section 732(1), (2) or (3);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is not a ground for the Court to refuse to grant leave for the purposes of section 732(1), (2) or (3); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is not a ground for any court to determine the proceedings brought or intervened in by the member in favour of the defendant.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (1), the court may, after having regard to the matters specified in subsection (3), take the approval or ratification into account in deciding what judgment or order to make in respect of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any proceedings brought or intervened in under section 732(1), (2) or (3); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an application for leave for the purposes of section 732(1), (2) or (3).

subsection.leadIn: The matters are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether the members were acting for proper purposes, having regard to the company’s interests, when they approved or ratified the conduct;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to what extent those members were connected with the conduct, when they approved or ratified the conduct; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: how well-informed about the conduct those members were, when they decided whether or not to approve or ratify the conduct.

section.name: s735
section.heading: No discontinuance or settlement of proceedings without leave of Court
section.content: If proceedings are brought or intervened in under section 732(1), (2) or (3), the proceedings may only be discontinued or settled with the leave of the Court.

section.name: s736
section.heading: Court may dismiss derivative proceedings brought by member under common law etc.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: after the Court grants leave to a member of a company, or of an associated company of a company, for the purposes of section 732(1) or (2), the member, in the exercise of any common law right, brings proceedings on behalf of the company in respect of the same cause or matter; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: after the Court grants leave to a member of a company, or of an associated company of a company, for the purposes of section 732(3), the member, in the exercise of any common law right, intervenes in the proceedings in question to which the company is a party.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: order to be amended any pleading or the indorsement of any writ in the proceedings brought under the common law, or in the intervention under the common law;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: order to be struck out such pleading or that indorsement, or anything in such pleading or that indorsement; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: order the proceedings brought under the common law, or the intervention under the common law, to be stayed or dismissed or judgment to be entered accordingly.

subsection.content: This section is in addition to, and does not derogate from, any power of the Court given by the law.

section.name: s737
section.heading: Court’s general powers to order and direct

subsection.leadIn: The Court may make any order, and give any direction, that it thinks fit in respect of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any proceedings brought or intervened in under section 732(1), (2) or (3);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an application for leave for the purposes of section 732(1), (2) or (3);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a refusal to grant such leave; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: an order under section 736(2).

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), the Court may do any or all of the following under paragraph (a) or (b) of that subsection—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make an interim order pending the determination of the proceedings or application;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give directions concerning the conduct of the proceedings or application;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: make an order directing the company, or an officer of the company—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to provide, or not to provide, any information or assistance that the Court thinks fit for the purpose of the proceedings or application; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to do, or not to do, any other act;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: make an order appointing an independent person to investigate and report to the Court on—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the company’s financial position;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the facts or circumstances that gave rise to the proceedings or application; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the costs incurred by the parties to the proceedings or application, and by the member who brought or intervened in the proceedings or who made the application.

subsection.leadIn: If the Court appoints an independent person under subsection (2)(d), it may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: order any or all of the following persons to be liable for any expenses arising out of the investigation—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the company;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the parties to the proceedings or application;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the member who brought or intervened in the proceedings or who made the application;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: review, vary or revoke an order made under paragraph (a); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: make any other order that it thinks fit for the purposes of that subsection.

subsection.content: The Court may, in relation to one or more persons who are liable for any expenses under an order made or varied under subsection (3), determine the nature and extent of the liability of the person or each of the persons.

section.name: s738
section.heading: Court may order costs

subsection.leadIn: The Court may make any order that it thinks fit about the costs—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: incurred or to be incurred in relation to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any proceedings brought or intervened in, or to be brought or intervened in, under section 732(1), (2) or (3); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an application for leave for the purposes of section 732(1), (2) or (3); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: incurred or to be incurred by the member, the company, or any other parties to the proceedings or application.

subsection.content: An order may require the company to indemnify, out of its assets, the member against the costs incurred or to be incurred by that member in bringing or intervening in the proceedings or in making the application.

The Court may only make an order about costs (including the requirement as to indemnification) under this section in favour of the member if it is satisfied that the member was acting in good faith in, and had reasonable grounds for, bringing or intervening in the proceedings or making the application.

section.name: s739
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: document (文件) has the meaning given by section 838(1);
record (紀錄) has the meaning given by section 838(1).

section.name: s740
section.heading: Court may order inspection of records or documents

subsection.leadIn: On application by a required number of a company’s members, the Court may make an order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: authorizing a person who is the applicant or one of the applicants to inspect any record or document of the company; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: authorizing a person who is not the applicant or one of the applicants to inspect any record or document of the company on behalf of the applicant or applicants.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may make an order authorizing a person to inspect a record or document if it is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the application is made in good faith; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the inspection is for a proper purpose.

subsection.content: If the Court makes an order authorizing a person to inspect a record or document, the person may, unless the Court otherwise orders, make copies of the record or document.

subsection.leadIn: If the Court makes an order authorizing a person to inspect a record or document, it may make any other order that it thinks fit, including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order requiring the company, or an officer of the company, to produce any record or document to the person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order specifying the record or document that may be inspected by the person;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an order requiring the applicant to pay the expenses reasonably incurred by the company in the inspection; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: an order permitting the person or, if the person is not the applicant, the applicant to disclose any information obtained as a result of the inspection to any other person specified in the order.

subsection.content: A person who complies with an order made under subsection (1) or (4) does not incur any civil liability by reason only of the compliance.

subsection.leadIn: In this section, a reference to a required number of a company’s members is a reference to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the number of members that represents at least 2.5% of the voting rights of all the members having a right to vote at the company’s general meetings at the date of application; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at least 5 members of the company.

section.name: s741
section.heading: Preservation of secrecy

subsection.content: If, on application by one or more members of a company, the Court makes an order under section 740(1) authorizing a person to inspect a record or document, the person may disclose any information obtained as a result of the inspection to a person who is an applicant.

The authorized person, or the applicant to whom the information was disclosed, must not, without the company’s prior consent in writing, disclose any information obtained as a result of the inspection to a person who is not an applicant.
